6 Ways to Catch Website Issues Before They're a Problem

\n

\nPosted by\nDave Schneider\n

\n

\n1/28/14 9:04 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n

Issues with your website can be absolutely devastating. Despite any of the marketing momentum or client base that you've built up, you may find your traffic ranking and following drastically tanking due to website errors. Lag, bad links, a lack of accessibility and even outdated content can quickly damage a website's SEO and lose the faith of its readership. Luckily, there are some ways you can avoid these issues before they even become a problem.

\n

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

5 Ways to Determine Your Website's ROI

\n

\nPosted by\nDave Schneider\n

\n

\n1/21/14 9:14 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n

Measuring the ROI of a website is incredibly important. At any time, you may be called upon to prove that the company's website is worth the investment, or even to defend your budget - and that could mean defending your salary, too. The ROI of a website isn't always as simple as presenting "expenses going out" and "profit coming in." Sometimes you may find yourself explaining your website's ROI to individuals who don't even know how to use the web let alone understand its value as a marketing tool. Before you can appropriately measure a website's ROI, upper management needs to have specific marketing, administrative and client service goals for the site in mind. Once you know exactly which metrics the website is being judged on, you can begin calculating the website's return.

\n
\n
\n

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Analytics\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

How Maintaining Your Website Saves Time and Headache

\n

\nPosted by\nDave Schneider\n

\n

\n1/16/14 9:19 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n

“I don’t have time to quality assure my site. I’m already swamped with too many other things, and that’ll just have to wait until life settles down a bit.” Sound familiar? Time management is a daily struggle for most website managers, and all too often they deal with pressing deadlines by turning a blind eye to the quality of their website content. Unsurprisingly, this usually doesn't go well. Here are three good reasons why you actually need to keep your site the cleanest when you’re buried under a heavy workload:

\n
\n

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Siteimprove Announces US Relocation

\n

\nPosted by\nDave Schneider\n

\n

\n1/14/14 3:41 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n

Siteimprove, the leading provider of Web Governance tools, has relocated their Minneapolis office due to rapid growth in 2013.

\n
\n
\n

On January 2, 2014, Siteimprove US moved into a new office located at 8000 Norman Center Drive, Suite 300, Minneapolis, MN 55437 as part of a major workforce expansion.

\n

Siteimprove’s Minneapolis branch grew significantly in 2013, adding more than 250 new customers and 13 employees.

\n
\nRead More\n

\n\n\n\n\n\n\n 8689803682:\n\n\n\n\n\nWinter Analytics Checklist for Your Website\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n

\n

\nWinter Analytics Checklist for Your Website\n

\n

\nPosted by\nKitty Ng\n

\n

\n11/19/13 10:28 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n

As the busy holiday season starts, taking a step back to evaluate your web analytics will greatly benefit your organization’s understanding of visitors’ interests, behaviors and most importantly their intentions. However, certain industries have marketing departments buried with work during the holidays, while others focus on more strategic marketing efforts for the upcoming year. Regardless of your organization’s speed of business, it is important to review web analytics before the winter to ensure you are reaching yearly website goals. Here are some starting point tips for reevaluating your web analytics: 

\n

\n
\n

Busy as a bee during the Holidays?

\n
\n
\n

If your organization picks up during the holidays try focusing on simple and attainable objectives you/the team can implement. Some examples may include:

\n

Create a report to identify the most popular “entry pages” into your website.  Understanding the origin of your visitor, creating content to match their interests, and easy navigation are critical to ensure a low bounce rate.  By improving the top entry pages to match the intended visitor’s interest, the organization fosters a stronger engagement with the user.  If you are running a holiday-specific campaign, you could consider optimizing your landing pages to ensure your visitors find what they want.

\n

\n

Evaluate your website by grouping similar pages to each other and review each group’s objective.  Are your visitors’ actions matching up with what the web team wanted or hoped for? Analyze the top pages of each group and identify if the visitor journey correlates to your organization’s objectives.  Creating a clear route within each group towards the objective ensures visitors are finding what they seek.

\n

\n

Segment your analytics data by external referrals and compare the traffic each source generates to your website. By monitoring your multi-channel marketing efforts, you’ll see exactly what advertisements your visitors click and also deliver your organization the greatest gross profit. You’ll also better understand the channels that your visitors prefer.  Be sure your organization’s website analytics tool tracks all clicks related to your marketing and website objectives, if not, what’s the point?!

\n

\n

Slower like a Sloth?  

\n

If your company slows down during the holidays envision your next year’s web analytics goals. By developing these analytics aspirations to actionable and quantifiable goals before the upcoming year, you will be able to start the year on the right foot. Now who doesn’t like that? 

\n

Track down broken links on your website and fix them.  Especially links clicked most often.  By fixing these errors, you will help visitors find the information they are looking for, without abandoning your site. This will also improve the websites bounce rate and visitor frustration, but most importantly eliminating the user from heading to your competitor’s.

\n

\n

Create a campaign tracking program to identify how users navigate to the website.  By tracking the sources of advertising that the Marketing Department use, you’ll have a more thorough overview on what types of marketing efforts work to drive the most interest to the organization’s website.  A great starting place for this project would be to track campaigns for email blasts, Pay–Per-Click (PPC), and blogs posts.

\n

\n

Is your website a driver for ROI or is it predominately informational?  Go through your website and track the pages which highlight your organization’s actionable goals. By tracking the pages where the most desired conversions occur, you will be able to easily scrutinize why certain pages do not produce the desired outcome.  In addition, you will also be able to see whether your visitor’s objectives match your organization’s website layout.

\n

For example, we can see that a majority of people who entered through our company’s homepage filled out our company’s demo request form and arrived at the Siteimprove “thank you” page. By tracking pages with our company’s demo request form, we can compare and analyze why our homepage draws more desired conversions and also find other ways to encourage visitors to sign up on pages other than the home page to increase overall ROI.

\n

\n

These suggestions are not exclusive and each organization will have different focuses, goals and internal programs implemented throughout the year.  This is a starting point to understanding your web analytics data and provides answers and suggestions to your department’s website objectives.

\n

Coauthored by Steve Hennigs and Kitty Ng.

\n

\n \n \n

\n
\n
\n

\n\n\n\n\n\n\n 8689816672:\n\n\n\n\n\nSiteimprove Partners with One North Interactive\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n

\nSiteimprove Partners with One North Interactive\n

\n

\nPosted by\nJessica O'Sullivan\n

\n

\n9/11/13 2:07 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n

Siteimprove, Inc. the world’s leading providers of web governance solutions have today announced a new partnership with creative agency One North Interactive LLC (One North) who serve the strategic, creative and technological needs of leading law firms.

\n
\n
\n

The mutually beneficial partnership will see One North offer their existing and new legal customers Siteimprove’s market leading web analytics solution. Currently serving more than 1,500 organizations worldwide, of which more than 20 are Am Law 100 firms, Siteimprove CEO Torben Rytt sees the partnership as the ideal way for Siteimprove to cement their stronghold within the legal industry.

“As an industry leader within our own field it was essential to us that we find our equal to partner with, which we definitely did with One North. Both of us pride ourselves on providing the best available service to our customers and through this partnership we look forward to offering One North’s clients a viable way of using analytics to stay ahead of their competition” said Rytt.

For One North CEO and Founder John Simpson, the decision to collaborate with Siteimprove and position it as the agency’s best-in-class web governance provider was an easy one.  

“Creating a seamless web user experience is critical for One North and our clients. We’re delighted to partner with Siteimprove, as we are focused on providing our clients with the tools needed to ensure consistent, high-quality user experiences. We also believe that more in-depth analytics will enable clients to not only quantify their success, but also help them understand user behavior and trends. We’re excited to be working together. ”

\n

In the future, Siteimprove and One North look forward to further strengthening their professional relationship, and to continue offering current and future clients the innovative services and solutions that both are known for.

For more information on Siteimprove please visit www.siteimprove.com

\n

About Siteimprove:
Repeatedly named one of the 100 best companies to work for, Siteimprove provides organizations of all shapes and sizes with tools that make website management and maintenance easier and more affordable. Founded in Denmark in 2003, Siteimprove has a global presence with offices in the UK, US and Germany.

\n

Media Contacts:

Siteimprove, Inc.  
Jessica O’Sullivan, Strategic PR & Marketing Manager
(612) 545-5662 jos@siteimprove.com

\n

One North Interactive 
Jennifer Bullett, Managing Director, Marketing
(312) 873-6875 jbullett@onenorth.com

\n\n\n\n\n\n\n 8689803452:\n\n\n\n\n\n5 Ways to Determine Your Website's ROI\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n

    • \n

\n

\n5 Ways to Determine Your Website's ROI\n

\n

\nPosted by\nDave Schneider\n

\n

\n1/21/14 9:14 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n

Measuring the ROI of a website is incredibly important. At any time, you may be called upon to prove that the company's website is worth the investment, or even to defend your budget - and that could mean defending your salary, too. The ROI of a website isn't always as simple as presenting "expenses going out" and "profit coming in." Sometimes you may find yourself explaining your website's ROI to individuals who don't even know how to use the web let alone understand its value as a marketing tool. Before you can appropriately measure a website's ROI, upper management needs to have specific marketing, administrative and client service goals for the site in mind. Once you know exactly which metrics the website is being judged on, you can begin calculating the website's return.

\n
\n
\n

\n

1. Use lead generation forms for additional value

\n

Providing leads is a tangible benefit that a site can provide, and can be translated directly into a quantifiable ROI. Even better, it's the type of benefit that marketers will always understand. The more leads your website can generate, the better its ROI will be on average. To improve your lead generation you should use lead generation forms throughout your website to encourage users to sign up for newsletters and alerts, or to connect through social media. Giveaways and sweepstakes are another excellent way to acquire leads; everyone loves a freebie. Once you've acquired these leads, you can begin the task of valuing them based on conversion rates.

\n

2. Calculate a net promoter score for sites without direct revenue streams

\n

Calculating the ROI for an e-commerce website is a relatively simple process: you simply deduct your expenses from income and you have your return. For websites that don't sell anything, such as informational sites or government sites, a net promoter score is often useful. A net promoter score separates your visitors or customers into three categories: those that adore you, those that could take or leave you and those that are actively working against you. You will need to be prepared to show the value of this net promoter score, such as by showing how positivity within your customers translates into increased sales for the company.

\n

3. Measure money saved through self-service portions of the website

\n

A website can lower overall administrative costs by streamlining regular customer tasks, such as by reducing troubleshooting time through comprehensive documentation or simply connecting clients to the employees most likely to help them. Not only does this save a company significant amounts of money, but it also increases overall customer satisfaction. The value of a website can be further proven through the use of exit surveys that ask the customer how satisfied they were with the self-service process, how likely they would have been to contact the company directly otherwise and whether their interaction with the website will encourage purchases in the future.

\n

4. Capture all possible analytics regarding the website's use

\n

It's simply not possible to determine your website's return on investment unless you're tracking analytic data from end-to-end. This is especially true of non-marketplace websites. You need to be able to determine which parts of the site are being accessed, how often and for how long. Additionally, you should be able to tell where the traffic is coming from, where it is going and how many visitors are actually being converted into sales or leads. If your website does not have sales or leads, you might instead capture analytics regarding readership.

\n

5. Identify the administrative benefits for employers and supervisors

\n

Many companies undervalue the ROI of their websites because they don't consider the hidden benefits it offers for both employees and management. There are many websites that operate as employee portals, facilitating communication, document sharing and project collaboration; these are quantifiable benefits that are nevertheless often neglected when calculating ROI because they don't deal directly with the consumer.

\n

Only websites that are stable, accessible and well-designed will be able to develop a consistent return. Siteimprove offers website quality assurance, accessibility, analytics and alert services to ensure that your website functions as it should and provides the greatest possible value to your company. Even better, Siteimprove is an automated system that won't waste your company's website budget on administrative tasks.

\n

\n \n \n

\n
\n

Topics: Web Analytics, Web Governance

\n
\n

\n\n\n\n\n\n\n 8689813902:\n\n\n\n\n\nHow to Win Friends and Influence Your Web Team\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
    \n

    • \n

    • \n

    • \n

Siteimprove Web Governance Blog

\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n

\n
\n
\n

\nHow to Win Friends and Influence Your Web Team\n

\n

\nPosted by\nDave Schneider\n

\n

\n2/5/14 8:52 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n

Stop me if you’ve heard this one: You’re the website manager, and you’re held responsible for the quality of your web content - but you have content contributors from other departments over whom you hold no real power. That means you’re held accountable for the quality of their work, but have no way to make them actually do it. If they decide not to fix issues that come up, it reflects poorly on you. Fortunately, there are ways to manage this situation! Since you don’t have administrative influence over these team members, you’ll have to rely on relational influence – which is better anyway.

\n
\n
\n

Here are five ways to win friends and win over the most obstinate of your web editors when you don’t have the power to force them do their work:

\n

1. Don’t criticize them

\n

Criticism won’t motivate them to perform better; it will only make them dislike you. Yes, even if you’re right. Avoid the temptation to “vent” to a coworker. Although you may be expressing honest frustration with a colleague you trust, those conversations tend to find their way around the office. Momentarily feeling a release of frustration isn’t worth the risk of making a lifelong political enemy.

\n

Instead of criticizing them, take a look at your monitoring and analytics tools to determine the areas of weakness empirically, and then work to understand how your discoveries affect them in their role. Using these tools allows you to approach them with a “new discovery” based on facts, rather than a negative personal opinion of their work. Always approach them as a colleague working to help them solve their problems, instead of a Philistine taking potshots from another department.

\n

2. Don’t argue with them

\n

Never approach them with the intention of forcing them to admit the error of their ways, because it simply never works. They’ll instantly go into defense mode, and fight you on everything. Swallow your need “to be heard” (AKA pride), and verbally acknowledge their objections as legitimate concerns deserving of carefully thought out answers. You never know when you might have overlooked something.

\n

Instead of arguing, use project management tools to clearly define issues and responsibility for everyone involved with your website, not just your offending party. As the proverb goes, “it takes a village.” Be careful not to single them out, and let the numbers speak for themselves. Chances are they’re smart enough to put two and two together on their own, even if they never let it show on the outside.

\n

3. Help them save face

\n

Now that you’ve discovered the issues empirically and clearly defined responsibility, downplay the fault and make it seem easily correctable. Be careful to only talk about the issues as privately as possible, and focus on the positives.  If other contributor jurisdictions have only a few errors, and theirs has dozens, present it as the area with the “most potential for improvement,” rather than the “worst section of the website.”

\n

Take great care to be tactful, because you can either win or get them to admit they’re wrong - not both.

\n

4. Speak their language

\n

Everyone is tuned into the same radio station: WIIFM (What’s In It For Me?). Step into their shoes and look at the situation from their perspective.  How does their participation in managing the website help them personally? Why should they want to help you?  Help them see how this isn’t just another menial task being dumped on them by someone who isn’t their boss.

\n

The best way to do this is to show how the issues may be affecting conversions in their area of the website, which may not always be a black and white metric. It’s easy if there are demo signup forms or something is for sale on the website, but what if you’re more informational, like a city government site? Departments may not feel like they have any “news” to share, and allow their content to become stale. What if your conversions happen offline, like when students visit a university website before sending an application in the mail?  In cases like these, you’ll have to spend a little more time thinking what the basic offerings of those pages are, and how they’re measured.  Are people downloading city maps, signing up for a newsletter, etc.? Are applicants downloading the application form from the website? What are the goals of that section of the website, and how do issues impede them?

\n

5. Lavish them with sincere praise for small successes

\n

Finally, positive reinforcement works wonders.  No matter how poorly you feel they’re doing, there’s always SOMETHING you can praise them for and mean it. Make sure you never give insincere praise, because it makes you look phony and manipulative. Find the positives and praise them as publicly and specifically as you can as often as possible.

\n

If everyone else fixes their small handful of issues immediately, and they fix a dozen of their hundred issues in a week or two, promote them as the person who made the largest headway.

\n

Ready to try your hand at motivating your team members? Remember these five tips, and let us know how it goes! Also, if you haven’t read Dale Carnegie’s How to Win Friends and Influence People, I can’t recommend it highly enough.

\n
\n
\n \n \n
\n
\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance\n

\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n\n
\n\n

\n\n\n\n\n\n\n 8718668632:\n\n\n\n\n\nFour good ideas on how to find the right keywords\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n

\n

\nFour good ideas on how to find the right keywords\n

\n

\nPosted by\nThea Straub\n

\n

\n6/20/12 10:48 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Keywords are at the very heart of search engine optimization and finding the right keywords can make or break your SEO success. It is therefore very important to find the right keywords to target. It is impossible to optimize your website for all interesting keywords, so you will want to start out with the most important ones. Here, we will give you four good ideas on how to find the right keywords.

\n
\n\n
\n

1) Put yourself in your visitor's shoes. Think about words and phrases that your target group of users would use in a search. Keep in mind that the regular visitor will not necessarily use the same jargon you do. So ask someone who does not work in your field which keywords they would use to search for your products or services in search engines.

\n


2) Make use of available statistics. You will find statistics for internal searches on your website in our web tool 'Analytics' under Internal Search. This list is very informative because the statistics give you the facts and not assumptions about what keywords your visitors are searching for. But remember that your internal search is limited to your website, which means it is often enough with a stand-alone keyword. In Google, a stand-alone keyword will often be too generic, causing searchers to make their search more specific using a keyword phrase of 2-4 words to get a relevant result.

\n

In the SEO module under Performance, you will find statistics on keywords from external search engines (such as Google). These statistics will tell you what keywords your visitors are using to find you in the search engines, but keep in mind that these statistics only include keywords your website already ranks well for and where your visitors have clicked your link in the search results. We cannot show statistics for searches where users have searched for your products or services and your link was not clicked or was not included in search results at all.

\n


3) Find popular keywords with 'Google Suggest.' When you start entering a keyword in Google, their autocomplete feature offers suggestions for popular keywords; try to play with this feature and see what keywords are typically used.

\n

 

\n

 

\n

4) Use Google's own keyword tool. Google has created a free tool with the purpose of selling more ads. However, the tool can also be used for purposes other than creating ads. You submit a few keyword ideas, and the tool suggests a lot of related keywords. You will have to sort through the resulting keywords with a firm hand as a lot of the suggestions will not be relevant. Take a look at the numbers in the column to the right (local searches) and find the popular keywords that are  relevant to your website.

Make a long list of all the keywords and phrases you can think of. Be creative and think about synonyms as well as descriptive terms. When you can't think of anything else, you need to start editing and prioritizing until you have a manageable list. Enjoy!

\n

\n \n \n

\n
\n
\n

Topics:\nSEO\n

\n\n\n\n\n\n\n 8718662692:\n\n\n\n\n\nWelcome to the new Siteimprove Blog\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n

Siteimprove Web Governance Blog

\n

\n

\n
\n

\nWelcome to the new Siteimprove Blog\n

\n

\nPosted by\nDave Schneider\n

\n

\n3/14/12 12:53 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n

We are proud to present you with the shiny new Siteimprove Blog.

\n
\n\n

We will be blogging about topics related to Web Governance, give tips and tricks for better utilization of  Siteimprove services and an insight into our views on topical issues such as cookie legislation, SEO, accessibility, etc..

We see the blog as a medium for a more informal communication with the outside world and hope to receive a lot of comments and questions!

Concurrently with the blog we will also open up for Twitter @Siteimprove.

We will be tweeting short news, status updates and links to external relevant articles and discussions related  to Web Governance.

You can stay updated on the blog by subscribing to our RSS and following us on Twitter.

\n

\n \n \n

\n

\n\n\n\n\n\n\n 8718700662:\n\n\n\n\n\nOn page optimization post panda: 3 tips to future-proof your website\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n

\n

\nOn page optimization post panda: 3 tips to future-proof your website\n

\n

\nPosted by\nThea Straub\n

\n

\n7/18/12 5:24 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Google regularly updates the algorithm that calculates a page's relevance to a given search. Last year in February came the much debated panda update, which has since been updated many times, even as recently as April of this year. Having just returned from the Search Marketing Expo in London, we have lots of good ideas on how to ensure that the content on your website meets the new requirements.

\n
\n\n
\n

With panda Google aims to weed out content without substance, ie sites with thin, useless, or just low quality content, in order to improve search results. Focus used to be on relevance, but now quality is just as important. It is no longer enough to find the right keywords and make sure to put them in the right places on the page. Now you also have to consider the user experience of the website as a whole, and whether it is a website that users like, trust, want to spend time on and  share with others in social media. Therefore, it is a good idea to follow these 3 tips if you want to future proof your website:

 1. Create good quality content - site wide

\n

First of all your content must be unique, grammatically correct, free of spelling errors and dead links. It also needs to be useful, informative, interesting and/or fresh. A website that is never updated does not give the impression of being particularly interesting. Last but not least, the quality must apply to the entire site as a whole. So you might want to remove low quality pages - or update them to become useful and interesting.


 2. Ensure great design and user experience

\n

Back in the day, you could search engine optimize a website, regardless of how it looked. That is not the case anymore. Both design and usability must be of great quality, ie. great graphics and images. Ads should not take up too much space. The usability of menu, structure, buttons, etc. must be considered. As an extra benefit, you can expect to harvest more links, more user activity, social media shares, likes and tweets, if you do it properly.

\n


3. Use statistics to investigate user behavior in order to improve it

\n

You can use statistics to identify sites of poor quality. Look at how much time the user has spent on site, bounce rate, page views, direct traffic, etc. Which pages have none or very little traffic? Which has a high bounce rate? Which receive poor user feedback? Pages that stick out and are of poor quality should be addressed. Additionally, you can also use the statistics tool to keep an eye on whether the changes you make to the website in general also improve user experience.

Quality takes time, and there are no quick short cuts if you want to future proof your website. Use your statistics tool wisely, and once you have removed poor quality content, then start improving your most important pages first. Then you can work your way down to lower level pages as time allows

Find more information about what Google sees as quality content on Google's own blog.

\n

\n \n \n

\n
\n
\n

Topics:\nSEO\n

\n\n\n\n\n\n\n 8718700542:\n\n\n\n\n\nAre you ready to manage smart-phone access on your website? \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n

\n

\nAre you ready to manage smart-phone access on your website? \n

\n

\nPosted by\nJessica O'Sullivan\n

\n

\n7/25/12 5:11 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

By taking a quick glance at mobile web statistics, we can see an obvious increase in mobile phone users. Every indication points to this trend only continuing to grow. According to an analysis by Morgan Stanley, it is estimated that the number of Internet users who access the Internet through mobile units will exceed the number of users who access the Internet from traditional computers in 2014. The analysis is from 2010 and whether the results will prove true in 2014 is hard to say, but larger and better screens on smart phones, more powerful processors and flat-rate data subscriptions have an influence on the process.

\n
\n\n
\n

The need of more smart phone available websites

\n

As explained above, the forward increased Internet use through mobile units requires a focus on optimizing websites to support mobile units. On many websites, especially older ones, the creators have not at all considered that users also need to access the websites through mobile units with screen sizes down to 320x480 pixels.

\n

If a website only is optimized to screen sizes with more than 1024 pixels across, it causes problems for mobile user experience and likelihood of a repeat visit. Mobile users typically lose the overview of the site, because they need to zoom in to read the text. At the same time, buttons and navigation are developed for mouse and keyboard use, instead of touchscreens.

\n

But a 1:1 development of a mobile version of a website is often an expensive solution, especially if external consultants is needed for the development work. Furthermore, technical challenges may arise in relation to how the solutions should be created. Most people know that iOS (iPhone, iPod and iPad) don't support Flash.

\n

User pattern on mobile units

\n

Normally, the user patterns on mobile devices are different from what are seen from standard PC-users. The statistics show that the involvement and the time spent on the websites is low and the bounce rate is high. All this tells us that the mobile users don't "surf" the net, but are instead looking for very specific information.

\n

The same pattern shows when we look at which content the mobile users view. They typically access sites with information on opening hours, contact information or prices.

\n

Analysis data for a mobile strategy

\n

Because of the difference in user behavior when accessing websites through mobile units, it is important to look at the structure of a website. As mentioned earlier, a 1:1 solution where the content is transferred to a site optimized for mobile units is often an expensive solution, but it's possible to use the analysis data to create a strategy to determine which pages should be optimized for mobile units.

\n

Try to map out the behavior of those users who visit your website through mobile units and look at the involvement as well as what content they most often view. You will see a clear tendency in what the users look for when they visit your website through a mobile device.

\n

If the top 10 visited pages are 90% of the page views in connection with mobile  access, then it would be a good starting point to optimize those 10 pages and make them functional to users who access the website through mobile devices.

\n

Doing this can make a seemingly impossible web project, the development of an entire mobile version of your website, reduced to the optimization of few strategic pages.

\n

\n \n \n

\n

 

\n
\n
\n

Topics:\nWeb Analytics\n

\n
\n
\n

\nJust like sports, websites should be accessible to everyone\n

\n

\nPosted by\nJack Oldham\n

\n

\n9/5/12 3:49 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

With the Paralympics underway, world coverage of the 2nd biggest multinational event has highlighted how sports should be enjoyed by everyone, regardless of their disability, but what about the accessibility of websites?

\n
\n\n
\n

As a company with offices in multiple countries and continents, we at Siteimprove feel it's important to be involved with our communities wherever we are.

\n

We recently partnered with Go ON Gold, a national web accessibility campaign in the United Kingdom. After partnering with them, we were shocked to learn that 43% of disabled people in the UK have never been online.

\n

Therefore, this post aims to raise awareness of the barriers that people with disabilities and learning difficulties face when using websites. Fundamentally, it explores how those responsible for websites can use specific web based tools to tackle and prevent accessibility issues. Before I start, it should be noted that online accessibility is an extensive subject, so I recommend reading previous Siteimprove accessibility posts and our recent white paper  'How to ensure website accessibility'.

\n

Why use a tool to improve your website's accessibility?

\n

Ideally, a website's accessibility should be addressed when planning and designing a website, however this is often not the case. There is commonly no plan in place to monitor future accessibility issues of a website; those that comply with the Web Content Accessibility Guidelines (WCAG).

\n

In short, using a tool speeds up the process by automatically detecting and identifying underlying accessibility issues, and any new problems that may emerge on your website as a result of new guidelines, human error or inexperience of accessibility. It also makes otherwise complex, extensive and time consuming manual tasks much easier by being able to:

\n
    \n
  • Have a large library of WCAG success criterion to perform checks from
    • \n
  • Automatically detect both site specific and page specific issues
    • \n
  • Cover all conformance levels
    • \n
  • Show progress status and historical views
    • \n
  • Highlight priority pages with most issues
    • \n
  • Provide detailed and extractable reports
    • \n
\n

Some common detectable and fixable issues

\n

As an experiment, I ran some tests using Siteimprove's Quality Assurance and Accessibility toolcrawling 2000 pages on two leading Paralympic websites, which would be fair to assume are top runners in having good accessibility.

\n

In regards to complying with WCAG, there were a number of Level A issues (minimum conformance level) which were picked up. For instance, missing alt text, which is a  1.1.1 success criterion of WCAG. This means that screen readers and blind people would not be able to understand what the image was, as there was no descriptive text. This was found on important 1st level pages, for images such as booking tickets, and dates for Paralympic reunions. To address this issue, appropriate alt text might be, 'Buy your Paralympic tickets by clicking here' and 'Click here to see dates for Paralympic reunions'.

\n

Another Level A issue apparent on a homepage was link text not passing  WCAG 2.4.4. This showed several 'Read More' links. Unfortunately this link text duplication is actually a hindrance to screen readers as they provide no description of what the link destination is. A solution to this would be to provide a description of that URL within the main copy, e.g "There were lots of interesting tactics during the football match, Great Britain vs China". Where "Great Britain vs China" is a link.

\n

Furthermore, tests recorded 283 broken links and 13 misspellings on one website, and the other had 874 broken links and 82 misspellings. Common misspellings, and punctuation errors included:

\n
    \n
  • 'Competiton'
    • \n
  • 'paralympics'
    • \n
  • 'bejing'
    • \n
  • 'olympic'
    • \n
  • 'defense'
    • \n
  • 'mens'
    • \n
  • 'diveristy'
    • \n
\n

These are basic principles and web standards that can be easily detected using a tool, as well as fixed by using CMS integration.

\n

One thing to consider when using any tool is that they should not be used for training purposes, and without having a good knowledge or understanding of accessibility. Accessibility is an extensive topic, which should be researched thoroughly before making any decision for improvement.

\n

Building a legacy for your website's users

\n

If you are planning, redesigning or maintaining a website, then my advice is that you stop to think about how many users you are excluding if not ensuring website accessibility; what implication it is having on your organization or business? Are you taking unnecessary calls or inbound enquiries? Is your SEO affected by your syntax missing structured headings, alt text, or not passing HTML validation? Does it affect usability?

\n

In next week's blog,  Helene Nørgaard Bech, Siteimprove's Senior Accessibility consultant will be writing about accessibility for mobile platforms, which is certainly worth looking out for.

\n

As usual, post your comments below.

\n

\n \n \n

\n
\n
\n

\n

New website – Think web accessibility from day 1

\n

\nPosted by\nHelene Nørgaard Bech\n

\n

\n8/29/12 4:40 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

If you are about to redesign your website, now is a good time to focus on getting a website that can be used by as many people as possible. Here are some tips on when and how to make requirements and focus on accessibility throughout the process.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Create an annual search cycle

\n

\nPosted by\nBarbara Hammer-Aebi\n

\n

\n8/22/12 4:41 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Create an annual search cycle to stay one step ahead of your users

\n
\n

If your website has an internal search bar, it's a good idea to always be working on your internal search statistics. If you want to stay a step ahead of your users, you can create an annual cycle detailing search queries by month.  Then you can track and measure which areas need to be prioritized and given more effort.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nEnterprise Search\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Lend the Search Engines a helping hand

\n

\nPosted by\nBo Vejgaard\n

\n

\n8/15/12 4:45 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n

If Google or other search engines can’t read the content on your website, they won't show your pages in the search results.

\n
\n

When you've taken the time to produce content for your website, you probably want it to be found and read by your target audience. Since the vast majority of users use search engines when surfing the web, it's a good idea to help the search engines in easily reading your content. Therefore, it's essential that your website is 'search engine friendly' in the sense that you should make technical and structural enhancements to your website to make it easier for search engines to read.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nSEO\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Avoid These Common Accessibility Mistakes

\n

\nPosted by\nHelene Nørgaard Bech\n

\n

\n8/8/12 4:47 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Find out if you use alternative texts, headings and forms correctly and if you in general help people with disabilities and dyslexia etc. on your website

\n

In this blog, we'll cover several common misunderstandings in connection with accessibility problems on websites. Find out whether your website is doing it right or wrong.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Search Engine Optimization (SEO) and Mobile Websites

\n

\nPosted by\nThea Straub\n

\n

\n8/1/12 4:55 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Last week's blog post was about the need for mobile websites. And if your website isn't already mobile friendly, you're probably thinking of doing something about it. However, not all mobile websites are particularly search engine friendly, so in this blog post we will briefly present 3 options to help you make the right decisions on how to go about building your mobile website.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nSEO\n

\n\n\n\n\n\n\n 8718667222:\n\n\n\n\n\nDo a Winter Checkup on Your Internal Search\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n
\n\n

Siteimprove Web Governance Blog

\n

\n
\n
\n

\n
\n
\n

\nDo a Winter Checkup on Your Internal Search\n

\n

\nPosted by\nBarbara Hammer-Aebi\n

\n

\n12/27/12 2:43 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

With holidays and winter weather approaching, it’s time to make sure that your internal search engine is ready for specific winter topics.

\n
\n
\n

Winter search topics

\n

You might think that "Christmas" and "snow" are the typical topics to optimize for, and it does make sense to make sure that the most relevant pages of your website come up at the top of your searches for these terms. However, the search terms that are being searched for most often during the holiday season are related to opening hours.

\n

In most organizations, opening hours change during holidays, and we typically see a spike in searches for hours of operation during December and January. Users also search for information about services that may have a change in schedule, like garbage collection.

\n

Preparing for search term synonyms

\n

Forgetting to optimize for synonyms of relevant words is a common mistake. Make sure that you catch all versions of the search terms being used. If you're working to optimize searches for garbage collection, appropriate synonyms of 'garbage' might include:

\n
    \n
  • Trash
    • \n
  • Refuse
    • \n
  • Waste
    • \n
  • Bin
    • \n
  • Recycling
    • \n
  • Collection
    • \n
\n

Additionally, opening hours during the holiday period should be searchable for all offices in your organization. If your organization provides services such as a library or a swimming pool then make sure that opening hours for these amenities during the holiday period are searchable too.

\n

Recycle search term statistics from last winter

\n

If you're looking to find specific search terms to optimize your internal search for, I recommend checking your analytics from last year. By looking at which search terms were searched for in December/January last year, you'll get a good idea for where to start this year.

\n

Share your experiences with us!

\n

Do you check and update your internal search?  We'd love to hear your experiences in the comments below. 

\n

\n \n \n

\n
\n
\n

Topics:\nEnterprise Search\n

\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n\n
\n\n
\n

\n\n\n\n\n\n\n 8739631532:\n\n\n\n\n\nGlobal Accessibility Awareness Day: Gain a New Perspective\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n

\nGlobal Accessibility Awareness Day: Gain a New Perspective\n

\n

\nPosted by\nKevin Rydberg\n

\n

\n5/15/14 9:09 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n

Close your eyes. Now try to read the rest of this paragraph. You didn’t make it very far did you? Imagine how difficult it would be to navigate a website or read a spreadsheet without the aid of assistive technology and website accessibility.

\n

Global Accessibility Awareness Day is aimed at fostering discussions within the design, development, and usability communities as they continue to build, shape, and influence new assistive technologies. The goal is to raise the profile and increase awareness around the topic of digital accessibility, which includes web, mobile, and software experiences. To help spread the word, we're offering our two-part Accessibility Certification Course to everyone for FREE!

\n\n

Web Accessibility

\n

I recently interviewed our friend Keith Bundy, who faces the daily challenges of living with a disability, to get his perspective on the state of assistive technologies and web accessibility. Keith is the Assistant Dean for Student development at Dakota State University and he was born totally blind. Below is a brief summary of our enlightening discussion to help shed some light on what web accessibility and assistive technologies can do, but I encourage you to check out the entire interview to see how optimizing your website for e-accessibility can improve user experience and customer interactions.

\n

What is Assistive Technology?

\n

Our blog about Assistive Technology detailed a wide variety of computer software and devices that allow people with, and without, disabilities to easily navigate and experience digital information.

\n

Keith has observed the rapid improvements in assistive technologies over the years, especially those that relate to Web Accessibility, and below are a few of the technologies that he uses on a day-to-day basis.

\n

JAWS®: To have on-screen text read aloud.

\n

Braille Display: To read and write on screen text via a braille keyboard.

\n

Kurzweil1000: OCR (optical character recognition) program which ignores images and puts text into an easily accessible format for visually impaired.

\n

iPhone w/ Voiceover function enabled

\n

PRIZMO: iPhone app similar to Kurzweil, but at a fraction of the price

\n

Assistive Technology Interview with Keith Bundy

\n

Here is an excerpt of my interview with Keith. Enjoy!

\n

KEVIN: Do you think accessibility is attributed to the devices, or to the improvement in how websites are built in accessible coding practices?

\n

KEITH: Both. Without the devices continually improving, accessibility would obviously be far more limited. I think there's also big improvement because people are beginning to realize that accessibility is a benefit and not just something that they ought to do. I recently read that in the very near future, over 20% of the population will need some form of accessibility. That’s not only due to the disabilities that may be people were born with, or developed in life, but as the baby boomers get more toward that retirement age and start developing more vision issues they can benefit from accessibility.

\n

So what we're discovering is the companies that design their websites with accessibility in mind are able to reach that population while other companies who don't are going to end up losing that market share in the future. So the fact that more people are aware of what accessibility will do and are learning the coding that will make things extremely accessible is definitely a great help.

\n

KEVIN: That’s great. Let’s talk for a few minutes about accessible documents. How many times a day do you encounter a Word file, Excel file, or a PDF document that you may have issues with, from an accessibility point of view?

\n

KEITH: Fortunately not as often as I used to. The biggest issue that I face today is PDF documents that can’t be scanned. Fortunately for me, Kurzweil1000 has a system where you can just open the PDF document and it scans the document and to convert it into a readable format, pretty much immediately.

\n

Word documents, if they’re long, it's really appreciated if the person writing the document will use headings, styles, and things that the screen reader can navigate to using “navigation quick keys” that can enable you to navigate by heading, or by table, or by certain styles. That's very, very helpful.

\n

The one thing that I would want to mention is webpages. I'm more likely to run across a webpage that's not very accessible. In my mind, there’s two levels of accessibility—legal accessibility and comfortable accessibility.

\n

Some pages are legally accessible, but not very convenient to use and I’ll avoid them if possible. Other pages are very comfortable to use and you can make a page really comfortable for people who have accessibility issues by using cascading style sheets, making sure that you use headings, making sure that you code your tables correctly, those simple things just can do wonders to a webpage.

\n

KEVIN: I completely agree. As we finish up, tell me the top three things that we could do to improve your web experience as a blind user, Keith.

\n

KEITH: All right, well the top three things, first of all on webpages use headings. One of the things I like to do is browse a page by just looking at the various headings, so I use them to separate various types of information. Don't use them just as the thing that everything's under, because the screen reader can’t separate that. If you have a title, make it a Level 1 heading. If you have a subtitle, make a Level 2 heading or Level 3 or whatever. That's the most helpful thing.

\n

Another thing is make sure tables are coded properly. A table can require a lot of memorization, if you're blind, if it's not coded properly and you can find some really good stuff out there on coding tables where the row headers and column headers can be read with a screen reader very easily.

\n

The third thing that would be really helpful is if you've got graphics, if they are important to the content, put an “alt” tag on those graphics saying what they are; maybe, if it's really important, use for “long description” feature to put a description so that if the screen reader user hits a certain command they’ll get that description. 

\n

KEVIN: Thanks for your time!

\n

KEITH: Thank you Kevin; it’s been my pleasure. I thoroughly enjoyed it.

\n

You can get the entire interview with Kevin and Keith here.

\n

 

\n

\n \n \n  

\n

 

\n
\n

Jessica O'Sullivan

Recent Posts

\n
\n
\n

Are you ready to manage smart-phone access on your website?

\n

\nPosted by\nJessica O'Sullivan\n

\n

\n7/25/12 5:11 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

By taking a quick glance at mobile web statistics, we can see an obvious increase in mobile phone users. Every indication points to this trend only continuing to grow. According to an analysis by Morgan Stanley, it is estimated that the number of Internet users who access the Internet through mobile units will exceed the number of users who access the Internet from traditional computers in 2014. The analysis is from 2010 and whether the results will prove true in 2014 is hard to say, but larger and better screens on smart phones, more powerful processors and flat-rate data subscriptions have an influence on the process.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Analytics\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Web analytics: gathering qualitative and quantitative data

\n

\nPosted by\nJessica O'Sullivan\n

\n

\n7/11/12 5:27 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

In basic terms, most web analysis systems are based on quantitative data. This quantitative data contributes to general knowledge about the usage of a given website. Everything can then be broken down into numbers and graphs to be interpreted by the person responsible for the optimization of the website.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Analytics\n

\n
\n
\n

How Will the Net Neutrality Rulings Impact Consumers and Businesses?

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n5/9/14 9:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

The debate over Net Neutrality has intensified once again and will likely continue to do so as Internet Service Providers like Comcast and Verizon push for a Federal Communications Commission (FCC) ruling in their favor on May 20, 2014. The outcome of this debate could have drastic impacts on the way consumers and businesses use the Internet as a communication and information sharing platform, so make sure you know what it could mean for you and your company.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nContent\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Take a Load Off: Reduce Your Workload Through Website Automation

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n5/6/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

We’ve all been there: deadlines are looming and there just aren’t enough hours in the day to meet them all. Website management teams are often too busy putting out fires and treading water to look for smarter ways to work, so we’ve taken it upon ourselves to do the research for you. Here are 4 great ways that you can save yourself time on things you already do.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

\n

\nPosted by\nSteve Hennigs\n

\n

\n4/30/14 11:13 AM\n

    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n

    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Updating your website with new content is essential for increasing search traffic, but it can also create content management headaches as your site grows and your content strategy evolves.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance,\nContent Governance,\nContent\n

\n
\n
\n

\n

\nPosted by\nSteve Hennigs\n

\n

\n4/22/14 12:07 PM\n

    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n

    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

In order to fully understand the success of your digital marketing efforts you need the complete picture. In this post we will review a key component to capturing information you may be missing, how to implement that process in your organization and provide some guidance on how to add some serious value when you are armed with a more complete data set.

\n
\nRead More\n

A Look at Assistive Technology

\n

\nPosted by\nKevin Rydberg\n

\n

\n4/15/14 10:37 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Assistive technologies are tools and methods used to make web information available to people with and without disabilities. With the leaps and bounds in technology the last few years, you may not be aware of all of the different kinds of Assistive Technology available.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility,\nAssistive Technologies\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Top-Down, Bottom-up: 2 Approaches to Better Web Governance at Your University

\n

\nPosted by\nShane Diffily\n

\n

\n4/10/14 1:49 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

I have heard it said that if a university was a country, it would last about a week before breaking apart in civil war. At first brush it sounded ridiculous, but now I think it actually makes a good bit of sense.

\n
\n

Think about it – a university:

\n
    \n
  • Has a large population.
    • \n
  • Is highly diverse.
    • \n
  • Is geographically distributed.
    • \n
  • Has lots of stakeholders and specialist interest groups.
    • \n
\n

So, short of calling out the troops, what can you do to get everyone acting in a unified way online?

\n
\nRead More\n
\n
\n
\n

Say goodbye to inaccessible PDFs on your website

\n

\nPosted by\nHelene Nørgaard Bech\n

\n

\n4/10/14 11:34 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

”We can’t upload PDFs to our website because PDFs are not accessible“ and “We have to provide an accessible version of our PDFs since it is not possible to make PDFs accessible“ are both common dilemmas experienced among web teams. Perhaps these are sentences you’ve heard or even used yourself?

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

How to Stop Putting Out Fires and be Proactive With Your Website

\n

\nPosted by\nDave Schneider\n

\n

\n4/10/14 11:24 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Everyone knows reactive marketing is ineffective, but far too many marketers are buried deep under a pile of emergencies to even think about strategic planning. What do you do when your boss comes to your desk every day to light your hair on fire with another emergency?

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Why Do My Documents Need To Be Accessible?

\n

\nPosted by\nKevin Rydberg\n

\n

\n4/10/14 11:03 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Admit it: “PDFs” aren’t usually the first thing that come to mind when you think about website accessibility. They probably should be. PDFs are nearly ubiquitous as a “final” document type on the web, and hosted PDFs are often the only location certain content is made available – especially for educators, the healthcare industry, and government offices. When they aren’t accessible, that information simply isn’t available to users with disabilities.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

How to Track Key Performance Indicators and Micro Conversions With Events

\n

\nPosted by\nSteve Hennigs\n

\n

\n4/10/14 10:57 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Website technology has evolved so fast that tracking meaningful interactions can be difficult: White paper downloads, form submissions, and even watching informational videos can all be seen as KPIs and/or MCs, but are often impossible to track with the “out of the box” functionality of most web analytics tools. If you want to track these critical data points, you need to customize your tracking code – a seemingly daunting task.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Analytics\n

4 Tips For A Fall Website Cleanup

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n10/7/14 10:02 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Clutter is OK on your desk. Sure, your co-workers will be silently (or not so silently) judging you as stacks of paper, coffee cups, and assorted knick-knacks pile up around your keyboard like garbage in a landfill, but it’s part of your process, right?

\n

Your website, on the other hand, is no place for clutter. Customers expect simple navigation, easy to find information, and useful content. If your website took the summer off to relax, it’s time to put it back to work.

\n

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance,\nContent Governance,\nContent\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

3 Tips For Creating An Effective Website Content Calendar

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n9/30/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

With the demand for consistent, high-quality web content growing on a daily basis, creating a Content Calendar is the best way to coordinate and organize your content marketing efforts and ensure that your brand remains top of mind with your core audience.

\n

Content Calendars will vary from organization to organization, but by compiling all of your goals, assets, and ideas in a single document, you’ll be able to piece together what can turn into an otherwise unruly and chaotic puzzle.

\n

Ready? Set? Go.

\n

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance,\nContent Governance,\nContent,\nWebsite Redesign\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Web Accessibility Checklist

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n9/23/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Our reliance on technology in everyday life continues to grow at an alarming rate. I’m willing to wager that the majority of you are reading this on a computer, your smartphone is within arm’s reach, there’s a tablet tucked away in your bag, and you may have even snuck in some TV time today. Some of our closest relationships are the ones we have with our screens and devices, floating in the pixelated waves of the digital sea. Despite how we may feel about being so reliant on our technology, there’s no denying the benefits offered by the latest and greatest gear, gadgets, and gizmos.

\n

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility,\nWeb Governance\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Website SEO Checklist

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n9/9/14 10:05 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

What Google says, goes. They are the Alpha and Omega when it comes to online search, and their search algorithm is what dictates how your website’s SEO needs to be calibrated. In order to receive the maximum return on your online investment, your website’s SEO needs to cross off a number of key to-do’s before it can reap the rewards from Skynet Google.

\n

If you haven’t been keeping up with Google’s latest algorithm updates, read our blog that discussed the evolving SEO landscape. Go ahead and read it, I’ll wait.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nSEO,\nWeb Governance,\nContent Governance\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Web Accessibility and the Law

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n8/28/14 2:17 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

There is a difference between web accessibility and web usability. For web users with disabilities, the difference often turns their experience with websites into a “yeah, but…” scenario. Yes, the website is technically accessible, but is it usable? Meaning, can the site be navigated in a logical way and can information be accessed with the least amount of obstacles possible? The difference is small on paper, but stark in practice.

\n

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility,\nWeb Governance\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

The Web Governance Food Pyramid

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n8/26/14 10:02 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Don’t worry, I’m not here to tell you that 4 cups of coffee a day and a granola bar for lunch doesn’t constitute proper adult nutrition. In fact, top that off with a pack of Twizzlers® and a Red Bull® and you’ve got yourself the first meal out of the official Corporate America Cookbook (on newsstands never). However, I am going to tell you that your Web Governance Strategy needs to have a solid structure and balanced combination of essential components in order to properly manage and maintain your organization’s online presence.

\n

And what might those components be? I’m glad you asked.

\n

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

The Foundations of a Website Redesign

\n

\nPosted by\nStar Bazella\n

\n

\n8/19/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Embarking on a website redesign is no small undertaking. It will require a substantial amount of strategy, organization, and company soul-searching. Not only will you need to ask difficult questions, but you’ll need to provide answers that satisfy every major stakeholder. This prospect alone is enough to deter some organizations from pressing forward, but there are steps you can take in order to not only streamline your redesign project, but ensure that everyone’s needs are met.

\n

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance,\nContent Governance,\nWebsite Redesign\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Higher Education & The Web: Reaching Your Audience

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n8/7/14 10:30 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Finding the right medium for communicating with the most tech-savvy generations can be difficult. With the abundance of devices, platforms, and channels available to students these days, universities and colleges are forced to make difficult choices. Do they focus their attention on a select number of channels, or do they try to spread their efforts across as many as possible in the hopes of reaching the largest audience possible? There may not be a single right answer for every institution, but recent trends should help make finding those answers easier.

\n

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Web Governance Ask Us Anything Preview #2

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n7/29/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

As our panel of experts are busy answering the brain-busting questions submitted for our Ask Us Anything, we thought we'd share a sneak peek at the wisdom of our friend and Web Governance expert, Shane Diffily.

\n

You can download the full Ask Us Anything recording here.

\n

OK, I know. "Stop talking and give us the goods." 

\n

 

\n

 

\n

 

\n

\n
\nRead More\n

The Web Governance Checklist

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n7/22/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Every organization has different goals for their online presence, a unique team managing that presence, and a distinct process for achieving their goals. What I’m trying to say, is that there’s no golden ticket, silver bullet, or metaphor in the world that will solve every organization’s web governance needs. However, there are plenty of ways to get your web governance endeavors started off on the right (or left) foot.

\n

Whether you’re just getting your organization’s web governance strategy in place, or need to get yours back to basics, here are a few areas to focus on.

\n
\nRead More\n

Santa Isn't Real: 4 Common Website Redesign Myths

\n

\nPosted by\nDave Schneider\n

\n

\n12/12/13 9:38 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Website redesigns tend to be treated as a magic cure for a poor web presence by many digital marketers today. Unfortunately for them, separating fact from fiction can be a sobering wake up call. Here are the top 4 myths surrounding website redesign projects today:

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

5 Reasons You Should Care About Website Errors You're Not Responsible For

\n

\nPosted by\nDave Schneider\n

\n

\n12/10/13 9:42 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

If an issue on your organization’s website doesn't fall under your area of responsibility, then it’s not your problem, right? Not so fast. Being part of a successful web team means ensuring the entire site is cohesive and error free. That means setting aside the mindset of “not my area, not my fault” and working with your teammates. Because guess what? A problem you pretend not to notice might just land in your lap later on. Here’s why you should care about mistakes in someone else’s jurisdiction. 

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

A New Web Governance Roadmap

\n

\nPosted by\nJessica O'Sullivan\n

\n

\n11/27/13 4:46 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Written by Shane Diffily. The value of Web Governance is that it can deliver a minimum level of quality for both operations, and online experience. Get it right and you'll have happy users and happy staff. But no online management system ever emerges fully formed. Development, evolution and sometimes revolution are all features of a maturing Web Team. Having worked with dozens of organizations, I now visualize progress in Web Governance as a journey made up of three phases. Use the 'Web Governance Roadmap' described here to work out the distance you have covered on this journey - and what remains to be done.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n
\n
\n
\n

Winter Analytics Checklist for Your Website

\n

\nPosted by\nKitty Ng\n

\n

\n11/19/13 10:28 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

As the busy holiday season starts, taking a step back to evaluate your web analytics will greatly benefit your organization’s understanding of visitors’ interests, behaviors and most importantly their intentions. However, certain industries have marketing departments buried with work during the holidays, while others focus on more strategic marketing efforts for the upcoming year. Regardless of your organization’s speed of business, it is important to review web analytics before the winter to ensure you are reaching yearly website goals. Here are some starting point tips for reevaluating your web analytics: 

\n

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Analytics\n

Siteimprove Wins J. Boye Web Idol of the Year Award!

\n

\nPosted by\nJessica O'Sullivan\n

\n

\n11/12/13 10:58 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Last Wednesday, November 6th, 2013, Siteimprove was honored to be able to compete in the annual J.Boye conference ‘Web Idol’ competition. Held in Aarhus, Denmark, the conference is a series of international events that aim to bring web practitioners together in an informative environment that fosters relationships and encourages knowledge sharing.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance\n

A Web Governance Framework That Works

\n

\nPosted by\nJessica O'Sullivan\n

\n

\n10/24/13 4:43 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

The first step in changing Web Governance is often the hardest. There is ample evidence that issues with politics in many organizations have resulted in Governance systems that are extremely resistant to reform. Nevertheless, change must happen eventually. The framework outlined below provides a starting point for this conversation.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n
\n
\n

5 Steps to Ensure PDF Documents are Accessible for Everyone

\n

\nPosted by\nJessica O'Sullivan\n

\n

\n10/15/13 3:49 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Written by David Herr. PDF content on the web continues to grow each year, despite the issues of ensuring the content is accessible to everyone. It is possible to create completely accessible PDF documents that contain all the rich content and offer the many benefits that PDF files provide. But until recently there have not been good solutions. Manually tagging PDF documents using Adobe® Acrobat Professional is not an easy process and is very prone to errors. Today I will discuss the basic requirements to ensure a PDF document is accessible and can be read using screen reader technology such as JAWS® or NVDA.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Website Accessibility Testing: How does your site look to a blind person?

\n

\nPosted by\nMarie Langhoff\n

\n

\n10/8/13 3:52 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Siteimprove unveiled a new initiative that saw Jacob Nielsen, a blind user, test websites live at the Danish Digitalization Conference as part of its initiative to bring web accessibility for the disabled and handicapped to the forefront of people’s minds.

\n
\n
\n

Jacob, who works as a consultant, is an avid user of the internet and enjoys the self-sufficiency it can offer. However, being blind since he was six months old means he knows all too well how difficult it can be to surf the net if you happen to have a handicap or disability. 

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

What's up with 'not provided'?

\n

\nPosted by\nJessica O'Sullivan\n

\n

\n10/1/13 3:18 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

In 2011, Google began to hide keyword data for encrypted searches, and this only applied to users who were logged into Google. They have now announced however that this will apply to all users and as such will have a significant impact. Up until now, we have been able to provide excellent insight into what keywords our customers’ users used in search engines but in the next couple of months virtually all keyword data from Google will disappear.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Analytics\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Celebrating 10 Years of Siteimprove Success

\n

\nPosted by\nJessica O'Sullivan\n

\n

\n10/1/13 1:58 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Today, 1 October 2013, SaaS company Siteimprove celebrate 10 years of success since first opening in 2003. Having started from humble entrepreneurship roots, Siteimprove has grown exponentially to become a truly successful global company with more than 80 employees, with offices in five countries and customers in 11 countries.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

\n\n\n\n\n\n\n 8689804472:\n\n\n\n\n\nSanta Isn't Real: 4 Common Website Redesign Myths\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n
