\nSanta Isn't Real: 4 Common Website Redesign Myths\n

\n

\nPosted by\nDave Schneider\n

\n

\n12/12/13 9:38 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Website redesigns tend to be treated as a magic cure for a poor web presence by many digital marketers today. Unfortunately for them, separating fact from fiction can be a sobering wake up call. Here are the top 4 myths surrounding website redesign projects today:

\n
\n\n
\n

1. "My new website will be in perfect condition when it launches"

\n

Unfortunately, buying a new website isn’t like buying a new car.

\n

While buying cars and websites both require lots of planning and research to find the right one, new cars typically don’t have serious mechanical issues when they roll out the factory door. Websites do.  Ask any veteran web developer if they plan to flip the “on switch” for a new website right before the whole team goes home for the weekend, and they’ll either burst into laughter or tears.

\n

A better analogy would be a heart transplant.

\n

You spend countless hours transferring things over from the old site, redirecting links, double and triple checking your work before sewing it up and saying a prayer. Then you spend the next month in observation keeping a close watch on the vitals hoping to catch all the complications and prevent a catastrophe.

\n

Common side effects include:

\n
    \n
  • Images and pages linked to the old site instead of being re-uploaded
    • \n
  • Large images resized in the browser
    • \n
  • Content copied from the old website carrying over mistakes
    • \n
  • New content inevitably creating new misspellings and broken links 
    • \n
\n

Yes, even if you hired an agency

\n

Mistakes are inevitable, even for the most elite professionals. When you’re dealing with the heart of your online presence you can’t afford to let it skip a single beat.  The customer getting 404’d by your ‘Contact Support’ page doesn’t care whether your web design agency promised a flawless website or Fabio riding a unicorn. You don't have either and they’re frantic.

\n

2. "The redesign will fix all my current problems"

\n

Many problems simply can’t be fixed by website redesigns. A decentralized web team lacking clear roles means anyone can create and remove pages as they see fit, so starting over from scratch is only placing a fresh bandage on a gunshot wound. You’ll be back to the Wild West in no time.

\n

Other problems can be fixed, but bring new issues with them:
Getting rid of outdated web content, inefficient menu structures, etc. can have a catastrophic effect on your search engine rankings. When you remove web pages or change the URLs, you lose all the inbound links you’ve built up over the years - unless you set up a 301 redirect for each one. It's a pain if you only have 40 pages, (spoiler: you have a lot more than 40 pages) but it's an impossible goal if you have 2,000 pages. Since you’re restructuring your website, a lot of those pages probably won’t exist on the new site to be redirected to anyway.

\n

If you keep any of your old web content, there’s almost a guarantee you’ll keep some of your old errors. If the most skilled web agencies in the world still make mistakes, you can bet your content contributors are human too.

\n

3. "My web agency will make the website accessible to disabled users"

\n

No. They won’t.

\n

…Okay, maybe I should explain a little:

\n

Website accessibility is a complex, ongoing practice. It‘s impossible for any web agency to guarantee a fully accessible website because accessibility has to be continuously maintained by your web team. Your heart surgeon can’t promise a life free of heart problems just like your agency can’t promise you a fully accessible website.

\n

A few common post-op issues that can’t be prevented by an agency:

\n
    \n
  • Using directional cues for instructions (“click the button to the right” – if a visitor is vision impaired, they may use a program that reads the website to them directly from the HTML. There is no “right” or “left”)
    • \n
  • Not using descriptive ALT text for images (reader programs and search engines can’t decipher what your JPEG is a picture of. This is especially a problem if you've put a graph inside a picture)
    • \n
  • Having all your hyperlink text be “Click Here!” (mobile users, vision impaired, and just about everyone else won’t have a clue where you’re linking)
    • \n
\n

Also, if you don’t test your web accessibility independently, how will you know whether your web agency is delivering on their promises?

\n

Shameless plug: Siteimprove offers free online web accessibility certification courses to our customers, and you can enroll in the courses by emailing our certification team. If you're not a customer, there's no time like right now to make a hasty impulse purchase!

\n

4. "We’re starting the redesign next month, so fixing our current site is pointless"

\n

A well planned website redesign project can easily take 6 months to complete when properly managed. But website redesigns are infamous for delays and scope creep for good reason: just about everyone in your company has an opinion on the website, and they’ll come out of the woodwork to voice it.

\n

Even the simplest decisions commonly meet death by committee. It’s not unusual for us here at Siteimprove to talk to teams who are months into a redesign and have almost agreed to a top level navigation structure.

\n

In the meantime your current website is visited all day, every day by people who need it to work right now. Maintaining top-notch quality hasn’t lost any importance to them, and it shouldn’t for you either.

\n

Siteimprove can help

\n

Check out our free ebook on How to Prepare for a Website Redesign.

\n

\n \n \n

\n

Have any redesign myths to add? Let us know in the comments section below.

\n
\n
\n

\n\n\n\n\n\n\n \n\n\n\n\n 8753970152:\n\n\n\n\n\nWhat We Learned At Confab Central 2014\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n

\n

\nWhat We Learned At Confab Central 2014\n

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n5/22/14 9:30 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n

What is Confab? It’s a 3-day conference aimed at sharing knowledge among professionals who understand the value of creating awesome content. People with backgrounds in Marketing, Design, User Experience, I.T., and Business all come together and challenge one another to think about things in new ways, approach problems with new tactics, and share their successes and #EpicFails in equal measure.

\n

We went as knowledge sponges. Here’s some of the stuff we soaked up.

\n\n

Content & Accessibility

\n

Derek Featherstone’s presentation, “Make Your Content Accessible”, provided practical advice and examples from real projects that looked into web accessibility requirements for content.

\n

Although he didn’t go into detail about WCAG 2.0 and Section 508 accessibility standards in the framework he provided, the takeaways he gave could get any web manager heading in the right direction. Derek discussed the importance of H1/H2/H3 headings, content consistency, and why web managers tend to front load content. Curiosity won’t kill the cat with Derek, who is a leader in Web Accessibility standards and practices. Follow him on twitter, sign up for his newsletter, and check out his website, because this guy knows what he's talking about. The downside is that you have to be willing to pay for the heavy hitting information...

\n

Our suggestion/shameless plug? Check out Kevin Rydberg’s Introduction to Web Accessibility webinar to get a lot of the same great information. Wink wink, nudge nudge.

\n

Analytics

\n

If you want to know what your customers and fans are REALLY saying, look at your analytics data. The data tells a story and, if you’re paying attention, it’s likely to be a bestseller for you and your team.

\n

Mike Powers, Dir. of Electronic Communications at Indiana University of Pennsylvania (no affiliation to the state of Indiana), gave a great presentation on using analytics to improve your website’s content.

\n

You can churn out content all day long, but if no one is looking for it, or looking at it, it’s not helping you achieve your business goals. Data is great for identifying patterns and trends, but it can’t tell you what to do. It’s up to you to listen and recognize what content is working, what content isn’t working, and what content you’re missing.

\n

SEO

\n

James Gunter, Head of Content at TruHearing, gave one of the most informative and entertaining, presentations of this year’s Confab with his insights on Google’s Hummingbird Algorithm. Find out everything we learned here.

\n

Search engine algorithms are getting smarter (duh!); Google in particular. Until recently, cramming your webpages with keywords and outbound links was enough to trick them into thinking that your website was relevant to the search terms. As more and more people began to “game” the system, Google got wise and decided to change the game.

\n

With their Hummingbird update (released in Sept 2013), Google made a definitive statement about what they want to be. They no longer want to provide search results evenly across companies and industries. Google wants to be an information broker. They want to provide users with the best quality content; content that is relevant to the search and is most likely to satisfy the user’s needs.

\n

What Google wants now is high quality content. Feed Google what it wants, or they will eat you instead. It’s that simple. If you’re creating content that people need and are actively trying to find, regardless of whether you were the original creator or not, you’ll be rewarded.

\n

 

\n

The good folks at Confab are filled with useful info, so check out their blog!

\n

\n \n \n

\n
\n

\n\n\n\n\n\n\n 8863526462:\n\n\n\n\n\nSemantic Markup and Web Accessibility\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n

\n

\nSemantic Markup and Web Accessibility\n

\n

\nPosted by\nKevin Rydberg\n

\n

\n7/17/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n

Web Content Accessibility Guideline 1.3, “Adaptable” is defined as: Creating content that can be presented in different ways (for example simpler layout) without losing information or structure. 

\n

HTML was originally designed to deliver documents with a structure that represented the importance and order of information. The creators of HTML were actually scientists who wanted a way to share technical documents. They didn’t really care about the visual look of the document as viewed on a screen—it just needed to correctly convey the information.

\n\n

Semantics and accessibility are a part of HTML by design. Still, they are not useful unless used appropriately. Understanding how to write semantic code properly means knowing how that code works, and how users and machines will read it.

\n

Semantic markup is a fancy term for common-sense HTML usage: if you write a headline or section heading, mark it with a heading tag (<h1>, <h2>). If you write paragraph text, place the text between paragraph tags (<p>…</p>). If you wish to emphasize an important phrase, mark it with strong emphasis (<strong>… </strong>).  Never choose an HTML tag based on how it looks in a web browser. You can adjust the visual presentation of your content later with CSS to get the look you want for headlines, quotations, emphasized text, and other typography.

\n

HTML also contains semantic code elements that are not visible but are extremely useful behind the scenes. There are code cues that make “reading” the page with assistive technology not only possible, but also efficient. Remember—we are simply providing good instructions with our HTML, and those instructions need to work well with assistive technology, too.

\n

Semantic HTML structure

\n

Content, Presentation, and Behavior

\n

Separating the content from the presentation and from the behavior allows us more efficient control over the different elements that make up a web page. For example, by keeping the presentational elements (styles) isolated in a separate CSS file, we can quickly change the look of a single element or restyle the entire site without ever having to touch the content.

\n

Semantic vs. Non-semantic (Presentational) tags

\n

By using semantic tags and styles instead of using presentational tags, which are only visual, the meaning is not carried through by a technology that only reads the code.

\n

Deprecated presentation tags

\n

For every presentational tag that has been deprecated, there is a CSS equivalent:

\n

<center> tags can use a text-align property, <bold> tags can use a font-weight property and so on.

\n\n

The Web Standards Model

\n

Structural Semantics

\n

We’ve discussed semantic elements that affect our text many times; elements like <h1> - <h6>, <p>, and <li>. Table-based layouts were slowly replaced by containers called <div>s and <span>s. These elements are considered generic and don’t really offer any semantic value. But now we have HTML5…

\n

HTML5

\n

There are elements introduced in HTML5 that help considerably with structure and truly give us meaning to our web page containers. A partial list includes:

\n
    \n
  • <header>
    • \n
  • <main>
    • \n
  • <article>
    • \n
  • <aside>
    • \n
  • <footer>
    • \n
\n

While there are many other elements introduced, these elements will be covered in more detail during this month’s webinar.

\n

Text-level Semantics

\n

Let’s stick to the basics and think about a few of the text-level elements as replacements for the deprecated presentation tags we talked about earlier. In fact some of those tags are available for use within the HTML5 specification. The key here is that the tags have a purpose; there is meaning behind these tags. Examples include:

\n
    \n
  • <strong>
    • \n
  • <em>
    • \n
  • <small>
    • \n
  • <code>
    • \n
\n

WAI-ARIA

\n

WAI-ARIA is a specification that has been added specifically to add accessibility and semantic value to a web page. An example would be to specify a list of links as a navigation menu. WAI-ARIA roles may be helpful with scripting, dynamic content, and advanced user controls. Examples of WAI-Aria roles include:

\n
    \n
  • <alert>
    • \n
  • <checkbox>
    • \n
  • <slider>
    • \n
  • <tab>
    • \n
  • <tabpanel>
    • \n
  • <treeitem>
    • \n
\n
Want to learn more about semantic markup accessibility?
\n
Download our on-demand webinar for a more in-depth discussion and examples of this important website accessibility topic.
\n
\n \n \n
\n
\n
\n
\n

\n\n\n\n\n\n\n 8873238662:\n\n\n\n\n\nThe Web Governance Checklist\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n

Siteimprove Web Governance Blog

\n
\n

\nThe Web Governance Checklist\n

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n7/22/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n

Every organization has different goals for their online presence, a unique team managing that presence, and a distinct process for achieving their goals. What I’m trying to say, is that there’s no golden ticket, silver bullet, or metaphor in the world that will solve every organization’s web governance needs. However, there are plenty of ways to get your web governance endeavors started off on the right (or left) foot.

\n

Whether you’re just getting your organization’s web governance strategy in place, or need to get yours back to basics, here are a few areas to focus on.

\n\n

Goals

\n

Does your website know what it wants to be when it grows up? In other words, what do you want to accomplish with your online presence? Is it to drive sales, boost brand awareness, share information, or act as a digital portal for customers to pay bills and enroll in classes?

\n

Your content should be focused on reaching a specific audience for a specific reason, so be sure to identify the “who” and the “why” before you begin creating content. When you know where you’re going, it makes it easier to plan out how you’ll get there.

\n

Roles & Responsibilities

\n

“I thought you were doing that.” When you hear those words, it’s already too late. Answering the question of “Who does what?” is vital to helping your team avoid confusion, streamline workflows, and maximize their efficiency.

\n

If you’re a one person team, this doesn’t apply to you, but know that we’re all tipping our collective caps in your general direction for your courage.

\n

For the rest of you, identifying the team members who are responsible for addressing issues like broken links, outdated content, or web accessibility errors will ensure that tasks can be completed quickly and without confusion or debate. Luckily, our good friend Shane Diffily explained how to address roles and responsibilities on growing web teams in a recent blog. 

\n

It’s important to keep your lines of communication open. Just because a particular team or team member is or isn’t responsible for something, doesn’t mean they shouldn’t be communicating their efforts to the rest of the web management team. This way, everyone will know when an issue is has been addressed, and if the issue manages to spill over into other areas.

\n

Policies, Standards, and Processes

\n

Establishing clearly defined policies for how and when content is, created/updated/removed standards for content quality, and the process for doing so will make your job less of a guessing game.

\n

Policies

\n

Web governance policies are meant to be high level guidelines which impact the entire organization and every online channel, from your website and blog, to your social media and emails. Policies should be few in number and only change when absolutely necessary or to reflect a seismic shift in organizational goals.

\n

Standards

\n

Web standards are more specific rules and qualifications which determine things like the voice and tone of content, the look and feel of design elements, or the specific channels and tools used to communicate your message.

\n

Processes

\n

Processes dictate the order and steps that need to be taken in order to add, update, or remove content from your online channels.

\n

Developing an editorial calendar will help you plan out these updates and provide you with ample time to monitor their success in order to determine what changes need to be made and when.

\n

Monitor, Manage, and Maintain

\n

SPOILER ALERT: Shameless plug time.

\n

Employing a web governance tool like Siteimprove will help your web team monitor mountains of content and data with the click of a button. By using our software to scan your site for broken links, misspellings, and content consistency, your team will be able to save time and focus on creating a web experience that will help your organization reach its online goals.

\n

Download our helpful checklist to get your Web Governance Strategy moving in the right direction.

\n

 

\n

  \n \n \n

\n
\n

About Siteimprove

\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n

Siteimprove Web Governance Suite: The only web governance software that helps you better manage and maintain your website through quality assurance, accessibility, web analytics, SEO, and response – all in one tool.

\n\n\n\n\n\n\n 9028100752:\n\n\n\n\n\nSiteimprove During a Website Redesign\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n

Website Redesigns

\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n

Most website redesign projects are a mess! Siteimprove can help ensure yours stays on track.

\n

Let's face it: whether it's part of a larger rebranding process, the old website simply wasn't achieving the goals set out by the business, or it just needed a new look, redesigning your website is a huge undertaking.

\n

Every department has specific needs, stakeholders have different opinions, and there will be plenty of bumps along the way. Whatever the reason, you've decided to take the leap and we're here to help make the journey as smooth as possible. 

\n
\n

      

\n
\n
\n
\n
\n

\n
\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n    \n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n\n
\n© 2015 Siteimprove Inc\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n\n\n\n\n\n\n \n\n\n 9028100642:\n\n\n\n\n\nA Look at Assistive Technology for Web Accessibility\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n

On-Demand Webinar: A Look at Assistive Technology for Web Accessibility

\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n

Assistive technologies are tools and methods used to make web information available to people with and without disabilities. With the leaps and bounds in technology the last few years, you may not be aware of all of the different kinds of assistive technology that is available.

\n

In this webinar, we’ll go beyond the screenreader — we’ll take a look at some different tech that you may not be aware of, or that has made significant changes to the way web pages are interpreted.

\n

What you will learn:

\n
    \n
  1. How Microsoft and Apple have provided exceptional assistive technology right in the operating systems
    2. \n
  2. Assistive technology that allows alternative ways to interact with a computer
    3. \n
  3. Assistive technology used by people with cognitive disabilities
    4. \n
  4. Making multimedia accessible
    5. \n

\n
\n
\n
\n
\n

\n
\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n    \n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n\n
\n© 2015 Siteimprove Inc\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n\n\n\n\n\n\n \n\n\n 9028099642:\n\n\n\n\n\nSiteimprove Webinar: The Foundations of a Website Redesign \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n

On-Demand Webinar: The Foundations of a Website Redesign

\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n

A website redesign isn't simply a chance to give your website a fresh look. It also gives you an opportunity to reorganize the way your site is structured and how your content is presented in order to support your business objectives. 

\n

If a site is going to deliver real value, it needs to focus on more than design and aesthetic considerations. Like building a house you need to lay the foundation, build the frame, and finish the wiring before you start slapping on paint and curtains.

\n

In this webinar we cover: 

\n
    \n
  • Re-cap of the How to Prepare for a Website Redesign webinar
    • \n
  • Foundation First: Content, Sitemaps and Wireframes
    • \n
  • Framing Fundamentals: Social Integration, CTAs and Website Assets 
    • \n
\n

You’ll walk away from this on-demand recording with a solid understanding how to outline and organize your site structure and how to map out primary, secondary, and tertiary content for your website redesign.

\n

 

\n

 

\n
\n
\n
\n
\n

We are here to help.

\n

We know that adopting new methods and tools can be difficult which is why our highly skilled customer experience team is available for on-going training and technical support for the lifetime of your subscription. Scroll down and view our latest online product training session options and schedule. If you are looking for additional training drop us a line and click on the ‘Request Product Training’ button and we would be happy to help.

\n

Request Product Training

\n

    \n

    New User Training

    \n
    \nRead more\n\n
    \n
    \n
    \n
    \n
    \n

    We’ll walk through the basic use of Quality Assurance and Accessibility in this 30 minute training session. This will include how to identify the location of misspellings, broken links and fundamental Accessibility issues, such as images without alt tags and descriptions.

    Wednesday, January 14 at 10 a.m. CDT

    Accessibility

    \n
    \nRead more\n\n
    \n
    \n
    \n
    \n
    \n

    In this 30 minute training session, we’ll review the Accessibility module. The focus will be on how to identify common, Level A, issues from the Web Content Accessibility Guidelines. We’ll also look at a handful of accessibility issues which overlap with SEO best practices.

    \n

    Wednesday, January 21 at 2 p.m. CDT
    \nRegister for this training

    We’ll take a deeper look at the reporting component in this 30 minute walk-through. We’ll also discuss the process of creating custom reports, as well as running and scheduling standard reports, and customizing email templates for the reports to be delivered in.

    Wednesday, February 4 at 10 a.m. CDT

    Analytics – Segmentation

    \n
    \nRead more\n\n
    \n
    \n
    \n
    \n
    \n

    In this 30 minute session we’ll explore segmentation in Analytics. We’ll start by using the homepage of a website to determine important areas for grouping purposes. We’ll also walk through filters one at a time and explain their specific purposes and possibilities.

    \n

    Wednesday, February 18 at 2 p.m. CDT
    \nRegister for this training

Helene Nørgaard Bech

Recent Posts

\n
\n
\n

3 ways to improve your accessibility right now

\n

\nPosted by\nHelene Nørgaard Bech\n

\n

\n5/9/12 11:11 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

It can be difficult to know where to start if you have not implemented web accessibility before. Where do you begin and how do you finish? Some areas require time and a targeted effort whilst there are some ways in which you can improve your website accessibility right away, and at the same time conform with 3 important criteria in WCAG (Web Content Accessibility Guidelines).

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

The added bonus of ensuring web accessibility

\n

\nPosted by\nHelene Nørgaard Bech\n

\n

\n5/2/12 11:19 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Are you looking to attract more visitors and retain happier users of your website? If so, then read on! By conforming with a number of accessibility criteria you can not only optimize the accessibility of your website, but also ensure good usability and increased visibility in search engines (SEO).

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Why do I suddenly have more accessibility issues?

\n

\nPosted by\nHelene Nørgaard Bech\n

\n

\n4/18/12 11:28 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n

Web professionals looking to improve their website accessibility using Siteimprove tools are finding that they have more issues in Quality Assurance, than they had in the former SiteCheck, but they are unsure of why.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

What is Web Accessibility?

\n

\nPosted by\nHelene Nørgaard Bech\n

\n

\n3/21/12 11:48 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n

The term “Accessibility” is often used broadly, but there is a clear definition of what we mean: ensuring that as many users as possible can navigate and comprehend a website.

\n
\n

Being in the accessibility industry, I meet many web professionals with differing thoughts on what web accessibility is. Some think that it's all about uptime and response time (Availability), others say usability, and some say search engine optimization (SEO) or "find-ability." Some believe that accessibility means that everything on your website can be read aloud in an automated way. I think you get the idea.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility\n

\n

Website Study: The State of Fortune 1000 Websites

\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n

Siteimprove used their Web Governance suite to collect information from the websites of 86 companies listed on the S&P Top 100. The results are summarized in this study. The remaining 14 companies were not included in this study as their website contained code that prevented our tool from analyzing their site without permission.

\n

This study provides benchmarking for your Fortune 1000 website's quality standards. Issues examined in this study:

\n
    \n
  • Broken links
    • \n
  • Misspellings
    • \n
  • SEO-damaging issues
    • \n
  • Web Accessibility errors
    • \n
\n



\n
\n
\n
\n
\n

\n\n\n

\nRoles & Responsibilities on Website Teams\n

\n

\nPosted by\nShane Diffily\n

\nFind me on:\n
\nTwitter \n
\n
\n

\n

\n6/3/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n

People are the most important part of any system of Web Governance. Hire good people and they will generally find clever and innovative ways to get maximum bang for your buck. However, roles & responsibilities have not kept pace with changes in online activity. This has led to dangerous gaps in operations, as well as tension among staff due to competing claims over “who does what”.

\n

In this article we’ll explore some of the ways you can restore 'industrial peace' by delivering the clear job descriptions your team needs.

\n

\n

On a Web Team where everyone knows what they should (& should not) be doing, all tasks have a go-to-guy and nobody has to worry about stepping on a colleague's toes. 

\n

On a site with low volumes of activity, this is straightforward because everything can be done by a single web-guy. Indeed, it is still common to find sites where a 'Jack-of-all-trades’ type Webmaster looks after all design, content, code, analytics, marketing and more.

\n

The only problem is that this 'all-in-one' model can’t last forever.

\n

Growing pains

\n

As a site grows in scale, a single webmaster won’t have the time (or the skills) to do everything. As a result, new staff must be hired and new roles & responsibilities created.

\n

The diagram below illustrates how this typically happens.

\n

\n

As you can see, when scale increases the Webmaster begins to step back from day-to-day activity and devolve responsibility to newly created roles. Among the first tasks to be handed-over are those in core skill areas such as hosting, code, design and content, followed by marketing, analytics and more.

\n

To keep things running smoothly, it is important you have a clear system for defining boundaries between new positions as change occurs. While the terms “roles” and “responsibilities” are often used interchangeably, they do in fact have quite distinct meanings.

\n

A “role” represents the key competence or activity for which a staff member is hired, while “responsibilities” are a description of the outcomes expected of that person.

\n

For instance, the role of Developer may be filled by someone hired for her coding skills, while her responsibilities are to produce code that adheres to best practice and organizational standards.

\n

If the shoe fits

\n

Of course, this is not to suggest that responsibilities must always be limited to a staff member’s basic skills. The real world doesn't work like this.

\n

Budget restrictions mean that people usually end up doing things that aren’t really within their remit, but nevertheless still need to be done.

\n

Most Web Teams incorporate some woolliness in this regard and it is common for the responsibilities of team members to be much wider than suggested by their titular roles.

\n

For example, responsibility for analytics on a mid-scale site may be allocated to a Content Producer or Designer even though traffic & data analysis are core to neither.

\n

(Happily, many staff have broad enough skills to cope, perhaps with the support of training.)

\n

‘Peak geek’ has been passed

\n

The good news is that as a site grows, much of this fuzziness fades away and staff can begin to focus almost exclusively on their own expertise.

\n

Indeed, a notable trend in Web Governance is the ongoing specialization of digital roles.

\n

While a decade or more ago you could run a site based on a team with broad code, design and content skills – this is no longer true.

\n

The arms race to develop ever more sophisticated websites has led almost every skill set to fragment into a series of incredibly niche disciplines.

\n

In fact, we have long surpassed the point of ‘peak geek’, where any one person could have a practical working knowledge of every web specialism.

\n

\n

From Content Marketing to User Experience Design to Universal Analytics and Technology, things are just too complex.

\n

This makes it even more essential for roles & responsibilities to be sharply defined, so that existing staff know what is expected of them - and prospective joiners know what they’re getting into.

\n

It’s always personal

\n

How you go about defining things is really a matter of choice, with no hard and fast rules.

\n

A suggested approach can be seen in the document ‘Web Team Job Descriptions’ available for download on my site at diffily.com

\n

You should note how each description includes a clear summary of the role to be filled, as well as a list of important strategic & tactical responsibilities. A catalogue of expected skills is also included.

\n

An important thing to remember is that however technocratic such job descriptions may become, they are among the most delicate professional documents you will ever author.

\n

This is because each one will ultimately be assigned to named individuals, who will take them very personally indeed.

\n

Experience shows that whenever a dispute arises on a web team, the first things to be produced are job descriptions. As such, it is in your interest that each one be as clear and up to date as possible.

\n

Web people are humans too!

\n

The problem on many sites is that this never happens. Scale increases, new activities emerge, new people are hired - but roles and responsibilities remain untouched. It is somehow assumed by senior management that the ‘web guys’ will be able to work it out and fill in any gaps.

\n

But nature abhors a vacuum and web people are as human as anyone else. Before long, staff end up jostling for position along unclear reporting lines as kingdoms are forged and jealousies accumulate.

\n

Then one day - perhaps as the result of some minor incident - things fall apart and someone is given the inglorious task of patching things up.

\n

While uncontentious anachronisms may easily be fixed (for example, a Developer who has traditionally managed analytics but wants rid of it), it is common to find instances where change is vigorously resisted. Say a longstanding Content Producer who wants to retain control of design rather than surrender it to a newly hired UX Specialist.

\n

While retraining or incentivization can go a long way to easing Governance transformation, in the worst cases it may be necessary to throw everything in the air and start from scratch; perhaps by defining new roles and requiring existing staff to apply for a position.

\n

A better future?

\n

Inevitably, this is all quite painful.

\n

Sudden, enforced changes to a web team are as disruptive as any other part of a business, as good people who have worked hard over many years are edged-out.

\n

It is my belief that many organizations are working through a period of heightened stress at the moment as this legacy of inattention to online roles and responsibilities is finally put right.

\n

On the bright side this also means that disruptive change is likely to be less common in future, as web management becomes more professional.

\n

So, if you find yourself in a bit of a web-team warzone, don't be too down hearted. Join me for a webinar on June 11 at 1pm (CDT) where we’ll be discussing the issue of roles and responsibilities in more detail, including additional questions, such as: 

\n
    \n
  • How many people to have on your team and with what skills?
    • \n
  • How should people be organized?
    • \n
  • Who should have overall responsibility for web?
    • \n
\n

\n \n \n  

\n

Shane has over 14 years' experience in Web Governance & online operations. As author of the first practical guide to Web Governance ("The Website Manager's Handbook"), Shane has also been published by A List Apart, Smartinsights & Forrester Research. For lots of FREE Web Governance downloads, visit www.diffily.com

\n

13 Tips to Improve Your Website for Mobile Users and Disabled Users at the Same Time

\n

\nPosted by\nHelene Nørgaard Bech\n

\n

\n10/17/12 3:46 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Smart phone sales are exploding, and the desire to make websites accessible to all users on mobile platforms is also increasing. I’m going to give you some tips on how to create accessible web content in the best way.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility\n

\n
\n

\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Like an athlete at the Olympics, your website should be fit and free from injury. This way you can achieve the best performance and value from your website every day.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Just like sports, websites should be accessible to everyone

\n

With the Paralympics underway, world coverage of the 2nd biggest multinational event has highlighted how sports should be enjoyed by everyone, regardless of their disability, but what about the accessibility of websites?

New website – Think web accessibility from day 1

\n

\n
\n
\n

If you are about to redesign your website, now is a good time to focus on getting a website that can be used by as many people as possible. Here are some tips on when and how to make requirements and focus on accessibility throughout the process.

Avoid These Common Accessibility Mistakes

\n

\nPosted by\nHelene Nørgaard Bech\n

\n

\n8/8/12 4:47 PM\n

\n

    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Find out if you use alternative texts, headings and forms correctly and if you in general help people with disabilities and dyslexia etc. on your website

\n

In this blog, we'll cover several common misunderstandings in connection with accessibility problems on websites. Find out whether your website is doing it right or wrong.

\n

Want to understand accessibility? Participate!

\n

\nPosted by\nHelene Nørgaard Bech\n

\n7/4/12 10:37 AM\n

    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Why is it important to be able to use a webpage without using a computer mouse? How does it work when a web page text is enlarged? How does a screen reader interpret a web page? Get the answers to these questions and learn why and to whom this is important.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

3 ways to improve your accessibility right now

\n

\nPosted by\nHelene Nørgaard Bech\n

\n

\n5/9/12 11:11 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

It can be difficult to know where to start if you have not implemented web accessibility before. Where do you begin and how do you finish? Some areas require time and a targeted effort whilst there are some ways in which you can improve your website accessibility right away, and at the same time conform with 3 important criteria in WCAG (Web Content Accessibility Guidelines).

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

The added bonus of ensuring web accessibility

\n

\nPosted by\nHelene Nørgaard Bech\n

\n

\n5/2/12 11:19 AM\n

\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Are you looking to attract more visitors and retain happier users of your website? If so, then read on! By conforming with a number of accessibility criteria you can not only optimize the accessibility of your website, but also ensure good usability and increased visibility in search engines (SEO).

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Why do I suddenly have more accessibility issues?

\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n

Web professionals looking to improve their website accessibility using Siteimprove tools are finding that they have more issues in Quality Assurance, than they had in the former SiteCheck, but they are unsure of why.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

What is Web Accessibility?

\n

\nPosted by\nHelene Nørgaard Bech\n

\n

\n3/21/12 11:48 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n

The term “Accessibility” is often used broadly, but there is a clear definition of what we mean: ensuring that as many users as possible can navigate and comprehend a website.

\n
\n

Being in the accessibility industry, I meet many web professionals with differing thoughts on what web accessibility is. Some think that it's all about uptime and response time (Availability), others say usability, and some say search engine optimization (SEO) or "find-ability." Some believe that accessibility means that everything on your website can be read aloud in an automated way. I think you get the idea.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility\n

\n
\n
\n

Siteimprove Web Governance Suite: The only web governance software that helps you better manage and maintain your website through quality assurance, accessibility, web analytics, SEO, and response – all in one tool.

How to Increase Conversions with Proper Web Design

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n11/25/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Conversions are measurable actions that users complete on your website, things like: completed purchases, form submissions, button clicks, video views, document downloads, or specific page views. Every website exists (hopefully) with a specific goal or purpose, and while the types of conversions may vary between different organizations, they all share the same desire to provide their audience with a solution to their needs.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance,\nWeb Design\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

How Can SEO Benefit Brick & Mortar Banks?

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n11/18/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Online banking is awesome. Everyone knows that. Checking balances, paying bills, transferring money, even depositing checks; online banking has made it easy for people to manage their basic finances from the comfort of their home computer or mobile device.

\n

But what about more complicated financial activities like applying for home and auto loans, planning for retirement, savings investments, or managing small business expenses? The average person will have questions. They’ll need information on how to start planning and who to trust with their money. And where does the average person begin their search for answers? That’s right, online.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nSEO,\nWeb Governance,\nContent\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Website Redesign Checklist

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n11/11/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Website redesign. Those two simple words are enough to make even the most seasoned of marketers break out into a cold sweat. Research, planning, meetings, debates, design, user experience, content, development, approvals, and that’s just the process for deciding whether or not you should do a redesign. The sheer amount of work needed to pull off a website redesign is often all it takes to make companies reconsider the whole idea, but it doesn’t have to be.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance,\nWebsite Redesign\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Involving People With Disabilities In Your Web Project

\n

\nPosted by\nKevin Rydberg\n

\n

\n11/4/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Involving people with disabilities on your web projects may seem like an overwhelming task, but if you do, it will be well worth your effort. The benefits will far outweigh the extra work, as you'll be gaining a much deeper understanding of how users with disabilities are motivated, how efficient your site may be, and how effectively all of your users can be while using your site.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility,\nWeb Governance\n

\n

Map your current web governance

\n

\nPosted by\nBo Vejgaard\n

\n

\n5/30/12 10:57 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Many organizations talk about Web Governance, but what is it – and why should you care? Simply put, Web Governance is a general term for the system of policies and guidelines you use for making decisions about your organization’s web presence. This system may be ill-defined and poorly organized, but it’s important to realize that you already have Web Governance. Thus, it makes sense to start working with Web Governance by mapping your organization’s current state of Web Governance.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Tell users about your cookies

\n

\nPosted by\nMie Elmkvist Jensen\n

\n

\n5/23/12 11:04 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Online privacy is a global hot-button, with lawmakers pressuring organizations to more tightly regulate the information they gather from visitors. The European Union recently enacted legislation dubbed the "cookie directive" has organizations scrambling to make their websites compliant. Many organizations in the US may not realize that they need to comply with these rules if they intend to operate a website in the EU. For those of you who don't run multiple sites, these simple tips may give you a head start preparing for future US legislation.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Show me the money!

\n

\nPosted by\nBo Vejgaard\n

\n

\n5/16/12 11:08 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

For most e-commerce websites it is relatively straight forward to put a monetary value on visitors, and therefore, it makes sense to put an effort into search engine optimization (SEO) to get more visitors. If you are running an information only website it might be a lot harder to find out how much a visit is worth.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nSEO\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

3 ways to improve your accessibility right now

\n

\nPosted by\nHelene Nørgaard Bech\n

\n

\n5/9/12 11:11 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

It can be difficult to know where to start if you have not implemented web accessibility before. Where do you begin and how do you finish? Some areas require time and a targeted effort whilst there are some ways in which you can improve your website accessibility right away, and at the same time conform with 3 important criteria in WCAG (Web Content Accessibility Guidelines).

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

The added bonus of ensuring web accessibility

\n

\nPosted by\nHelene Nørgaard Bech\n

\n

\n5/2/12 11:19 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Are you looking to attract more visitors and retain happier users of your website? If so, then read on! By conforming with a number of accessibility criteria you can not only optimize the accessibility of your website, but also ensure good usability and increased visibility in search engines (SEO).

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility\n

Q&A on the Basics of Web Accessibility

\n

\nPosted by\nKevin Rydberg\n

\n

\n2/11/14 9:01 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n

We get a lot of questions on web accessibility here at Siteimprove, and want to take this opportunity to answer as many of them as we can. This may be more of a review for you seasoned accessibility folks, but there’s a growing demand for this introductory information as more web professionals recognize the importance of accessibility. 

\n

\n
\nRead More\n
\n
\n
\n

How to Win Friends and Influence Your Web Team

\n

\nPosted by\nDave Schneider\n

\n

\n2/5/14 8:52 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n

Stop me if you’ve heard this one: You’re the website manager, and you’re held responsible for the quality of your web content - but you have content contributors from other departments over whom you hold no real power. That means you’re held accountable for the quality of their work, but have no way to make them actually do it. If they decide not to fix issues that come up, it reflects poorly on you. Fortunately, there are ways to manage this situation! Since you don’t have administrative influence over these team members, you’ll have to rely on relational influence – which is better anyway.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance\n

\n\n\n\n\n\n\n \n
\n\n\n\n\n\n\n 9792110402:\n\n\n\n\n\n3 Necessary Activities & Skills for Effective Web Analytics\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
    \n
  • Features
    • \n
  • Industries
    • \n
  • Knowledge
    • \n
  • About
    • \n
\n

\n
\n
\n
\n
\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

\n

Siteimprove Web Governance Blog

\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n

\n3 Necessary Activities & Skills for Effective Web Analytics\n

\n

\nPosted by\nSteve Hennigs\n

\n

\n10/21/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n

Getting an effective digital analytics process in place is a common challenge faced by many organizations. It’s often a problem of not understanding what an effective process looks like, or knowing what’s needed to carry that process out.

\n

This leads to the wrong resources being used, essential steps being passed over, and/or underestimating the amount of resources needed to get this right. In the upcoming webinar, we’ll take a look at the three main activities an organization must perform for effective digital analysis and the three skills needed to perform those activities well. By attending this webinar, attendees will have a better understanding of how to implement a process that works and the resources needed to do so.

\n\n

So let’s start by introducing the three activities and resources are needed, regardless of the digital channel you are looking to analyze (website, blog, social, etc).

\n

Activities

\n
    \n
  1. Data Capture
    2. \n
  2. Data Analysis
    3. \n
  3. Data Reporting
    4. \n
\n

Resources

\n
    \n
  1. Leadership
    2. \n
  2. Web Analyst
    3. \n
  3. Front End Developer
    4. \n
\n

Simple right? Well let’s take a bit of a deeper look at what each of these really mean starting with the resources. Once those are defined, we can review the activities and the roles each resource plays. An important thing to remember with the resources is that they don’t need to be three different people. One person can fulfill multiples roles if they have the proper skillset. Also, the resources do not always need to be internal to your organization. An outside company (like Siteimprove) may be able to fill one or more of these roles for you.

\n

Leadership

\n

This person confirms the strategy for analyzing the channel. They don’t need to have a full blown understanding of digital analytics, but a high level knowledge is helpful. What they do need to have is a full understanding of your organization’s goals, and how digital fits in to those goals. They also need the authority to make decisions around the website.

\n

Analyst

\n

This is the person actually working with the data and making recommendations. They need a full understanding of digital analytics and the tool(s) being used. They should also have a good understanding of the organization’s goals.

\n

Front-end developer

\n

This person needs to be able to carry out front end development work, especially around JavaScript. They also need a good understanding of the analytics tool(s) that your organization has chosen.

\n

Now that we have a high level understanding of the resources we need it is time to have a look at the activities in a little more detail.

\n

Data Capture

\n

This is the act of determining Key Performance Indicators (KPIs) for the channel that you’ll be analyzing, and then implementing your analytics tool to track those items effectively. Each resource plays a role here.

\n
    \n
  • The Analyst will recommend what to track
    • \n
  • Leadership will decide what to track
    • \n
  • The Front End Developer will implement the tracking
    • \n
\n

Data Analysis

\n

This is where the Analyst will dive into the gathered data in an attempt to make some sense of it all. They’ll need to review the KPIs and use solid segmentation to ultimately recommend how the organization should improve upon the current performance. The Analyst is the only resource required for this activity.

\n

Data Reporting

\n

Here the Analyst will take their findings and turn them into something that Leadership can understand and, ultimately, use to make decisions. It’s not enough to report on basic things like monthly visits; there must be some recommended actions from the Analyst in order for anything meaningful to come out of the report. Leadership must then review the recommendations, and implement any changes or projects that are necessary for improvement. After that, the whole cycle starts over again.

\n

It’s not easy getting an effective digital analytics program off the ground if you don’t have a good framework established. By making sure that you have the appropriate resources performing the necessary activities mentioned above, your organization has a much better chance at being successful.

\n

Please join me in the upcoming webinar as we dive into the activities and resources in much more detail. I look forward to seeing you there!

\n

\n \n \n

\n

Image courtesy of Pong at FreeDigitalPhotos.net

\n
\n

\n\n\n\n\n\n\n 9792122292:\n\n\n\n\n\nSemantic Markup and Web Accessibility\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n

\n

\nSemantic Markup and Web Accessibility\n

\n

\nPosted by\nKevin Rydberg\n

\n

\n7/17/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n

Web Content Accessibility Guideline 1.3, “Adaptable” is defined as: Creating content that can be presented in different ways (for example simpler layout) without losing information or structure. 

\n

HTML was originally designed to deliver documents with a structure that represented the importance and order of information. The creators of HTML were actually scientists who wanted a way to share technical documents. They didn’t really care about the visual look of the document as viewed on a screen—it just needed to correctly convey the information.

\n\n

Semantics and accessibility are a part of HTML by design. Still, they are not useful unless used appropriately. Understanding how to write semantic code properly means knowing how that code works, and how users and machines will read it.

\n

Semantic markup is a fancy term for common-sense HTML usage: if you write a headline or section heading, mark it with a heading tag (<h1>, <h2>). If you write paragraph text, place the text between paragraph tags (<p>…</p>). If you wish to emphasize an important phrase, mark it with strong emphasis (<strong>… </strong>).  Never choose an HTML tag based on how it looks in a web browser. You can adjust the visual presentation of your content later with CSS to get the look you want for headlines, quotations, emphasized text, and other typography.

\n

HTML also contains semantic code elements that are not visible but are extremely useful behind the scenes. There are code cues that make “reading” the page with assistive technology not only possible, but also efficient. Remember—we are simply providing good instructions with our HTML, and those instructions need to work well with assistive technology, too.

\n

Semantic HTML structure

\n

Content, Presentation, and Behavior

\n

Separating the content from the presentation and from the behavior allows us more efficient control over the different elements that make up a web page. For example, by keeping the presentational elements (styles) isolated in a separate CSS file, we can quickly change the look of a single element or restyle the entire site without ever having to touch the content.

\n

Semantic vs. Non-semantic (Presentational) tags

\n

By using semantic tags and styles instead of using presentational tags, which are only visual, the meaning is not carried through by a technology that only reads the code.

\n

Deprecated presentation tags

\n

For every presentational tag that has been deprecated, there is a CSS equivalent:

\n

<center> tags can use a text-align property, <bold> tags can use a font-weight property and so on.

\n\n

The Web Standards Model

\n

Structural Semantics

\n

We’ve discussed semantic elements that affect our text many times; elements like <h1> - <h6>, <p>, and <li>. Table-based layouts were slowly replaced by containers called <div>s and <span>s. These elements are considered generic and don’t really offer any semantic value. But now we have HTML5…

\n

HTML5

\n

There are elements introduced in HTML5 that help considerably with structure and truly give us meaning to our web page containers. A partial list includes:

\n
    \n
  • <header>
    • \n
  • <main>
    • \n
  • <article>
    • \n
  • <aside>
    • \n
  • <footer>
    • \n
\n

While there are many other elements introduced, these elements will be covered in more detail during this month’s webinar.

\n

Text-level Semantics

\n

Let’s stick to the basics and think about a few of the text-level elements as replacements for the deprecated presentation tags we talked about earlier. In fact some of those tags are available for use within the HTML5 specification. The key here is that the tags have a purpose; there is meaning behind these tags. Examples include:

\n
    \n
  • <strong>
    • \n
  • <em>
    • \n
  • <small>
    • \n
  • <code>
    • \n
\n

WAI-ARIA

\n

WAI-ARIA is a specification that has been added specifically to add accessibility and semantic value to a web page. An example would be to specify a list of links as a navigation menu. WAI-ARIA roles may be helpful with scripting, dynamic content, and advanced user controls. Examples of WAI-Aria roles include:

\n
    \n
  • <alert>
    • \n
  • <checkbox>
    • \n
  • <slider>
    • \n
  • <tab>
    • \n
  • <tabpanel>
    • \n
  • <treeitem>
    • \n
\n
Want to learn more about semantic markup accessibility?
\n
Download our on-demand webinar for a more in-depth discussion and examples of this important website accessibility topic.
\n
\n \n \n
\n
\n
\n
\n

Why You Might Want To Rethink That Website Redesign

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n1/6/15 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Redesigning your website and expecting all of your problems to disappear is like buying a new house because you’re too lazy to clean the one you live in now. Oh, it'll look nice for a while, but eventually you’ll be up to your armpits in clutter again. The same goes for your website. Slapping on a fresh coat of paint might make it look shiny and sleek, but the fundamental problems will remain below the surface.

\n

Spending time, money, and energy on driving traffic to a broken website is a massive waste of resources. Users might be flooding your site, but if all they find are broken links, poor navigation, a lack of direction, and accessibility issues, the frustrating experience will turn them off for good.

\n

The good news? These are all issues that can be addressed on your existing site. So, what can you do instead?

\n

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nSEO,\nAccessibility,\nWeb Governance,\nContent,\nWebsite Redesign,\nWeb Design\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Step 1: Write Well. Step 2: Be Successful.

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n12/16/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

The written word has been the cornerstone of human communication since roughly 3,000 B.C. I might be a little biased here, but even as we’ve moved from stone, to pen, to the ever-present keyboard, how you write is more important than ever. The Internet demands good writing. In the Digital Age, your audience’s first interaction with you/your company is often with the words you’ve written. Websites, blogs, social media, email; it’s all vying for the attention of an audience with debilitating A.D.D., and the organizations that prioritize the quality of their web content are the ones who will rise to the top.

\n

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance,\nContent\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Producing High-Quality Web Content: A Guided Tour

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n12/9/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

If you're one of those people who can just wake up in the morning, pour yourself a cup of your preferred breakfast-time libation, and start pounding away at your keyboard until something great comes out, we’re officially fighting and I’d like you to leave now.

\n

OK, good. They’re gone.

\n

For us common-folk, creating great content takes time, and it doesn’t happen in a vacuum. It requires a team-effort, as you’ll need input from subject matter experts and buy-in from your co-workers/bosses in order to turn a slab of rock into a piece of chiseled marble.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance,\nContent Governance,\nContent\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

How to be Agile in a Rigid System with Web Governance

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n12/2/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

No organization is perfect. Big or small, B2B or B2C, every company faces challenges when it comes to managing their online presence. Resources are scarce, money is tight, and office politics might make you feel like you’re playing the Game of Thrones. You need help to address these issues and find a solution that gets results.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

How to Increase Conversions with Proper Web Design

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n11/25/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Conversions are measurable actions that users complete on your website, things like: completed purchases, form submissions, button clicks, video views, document downloads, or specific page views. Every website exists (hopefully) with a specific goal or purpose, and while the types of conversions may vary between different organizations, they all share the same desire to provide their audience with a solution to their needs.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance,\nWeb Design\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

How Can SEO Benefit Brick & Mortar Banks?

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n11/18/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Online banking is awesome. Everyone knows that. Checking balances, paying bills, transferring money, even depositing checks; online banking has made it easy for people to manage their basic finances from the comfort of their home computer or mobile device.

\n

But what about more complicated financial activities like applying for home and auto loans, planning for retirement, savings investments, or managing small business expenses? The average person will have questions. They’ll need information on how to start planning and who to trust with their money. And where does the average person begin their search for answers? That’s right, online.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nSEO,\nWeb Governance,\nContent\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Website Redesign Checklist

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n11/11/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Website redesign. Those two simple words are enough to make even the most seasoned of marketers break out into a cold sweat. Research, planning, meetings, debates, design, user experience, content, development, approvals, and that’s just the process for deciding whether or not you should do a redesign. The sheer amount of work needed to pull off a website redesign is often all it takes to make companies reconsider the whole idea, but it doesn’t have to be.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance,\nWebsite Redesign\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Involving People With Disabilities In Your Web Project

\n

\nPosted by\nKevin Rydberg\n

\n

\n11/4/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Involving people with disabilities on your web projects may seem like an overwhelming task, but if you do, it will be well worth your effort. The benefits will far outweigh the extra work, as you'll be gaining a much deeper understanding of how users with disabilities are motivated, how efficient your site may be, and how effectively all of your users can be while using your site.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility,\nWeb Governance\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Web Content, Your Audience, and Search Engines

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n10/28/14 10:03 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Quality over quantity, right? “But wait”, you say. “I thought that adding more content and blogs would help boost my site’s SEO rankings?” Well, yes and no. Simply cramming your website full of unfocused, aimless ramblings is actually a sure fire way to earn the ire of both your readers and that company whose name rhymes with “Moogle”. It’s Google. I’m talking about Google.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nSEO,\nWeb Governance,\nContent Governance,\nContent\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

3 Necessary Activities & Skills for Effective Web Analytics

\n

\nPosted by\nSteve Hennigs\n

\n

\n10/21/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Getting an effective digital analytics process in place is a common challenge faced by many organizations. It’s often a problem of not understanding what an effective process looks like, or knowing what’s needed to carry that process out.

\n

This leads to the wrong resources being used, essential steps being passed over, and/or underestimating the amount of resources needed to get this right. In the upcoming webinar, we’ll take a look at the three main activities an organization must perform for effective digital analysis and the three skills needed to perform those activities well. By attending this webinar, attendees will have a better understanding of how to implement a process that works and the resources needed to do so.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Analytics\n

Celebrating 10 Years of Siteimprove Success

\n

\nPosted by\nJessica O'Sullivan\n

\n

\n10/1/13 1:58 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Today, 1 October 2013, SaaS company Siteimprove celebrate 10 years of success since first opening in 2003. Having started from humble entrepreneurship roots, Siteimprove has grown exponentially to become a truly successful global company with more than 80 employees, with offices in five countries and customers in 11 countries.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nSEO,\nAccessibility,\nEnterprise Search,\nWeb Governance,\nResponsibility,\nWeb Analytics\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Do a Winter Checkup on Your Internal Search

\n

\nPosted by\nBarbara Hammer-Aebi\n

\n

\n12/27/12 2:43 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

With holidays and winter weather approaching, it’s time to make sure that your internal search engine is ready for specific winter topics.

\n
\n
\n

Winter search topics

\n

You might think that "Christmas" and "snow" are the typical topics to optimize for, and it does make sense to make sure that the most relevant pages of your website come up at the top of your searches for these terms. However, the search terms that are being searched for most often during the holiday season are related to opening hours.

\n

In most organizations, opening hours change during holidays, and we typically see a spike in searches for hours of operation during December and January. Users also search for information about services that may have a change in schedule, like garbage collection.

\n

Preparing for search term synonyms

\n

Forgetting to optimize for synonyms of relevant words is a common mistake. Make sure that you catch all versions of the search terms being used. If you're working to optimize searches for garbage collection, appropriate synonyms of 'garbage' might include:

\n
    \n
  • Trash
    • \n
  • Refuse
    • \n
  • Waste
    • \n
  • Bin
    • \n
  • Recycling
    • \n
  • Collection
    • \n
\n

Additionally, opening hours during the holiday period should be searchable for all offices in your organization. If your organization provides services such as a library or a swimming pool then make sure that opening hours for these amenities during the holiday period are searchable too.

\n

Recycle search term statistics from last winter

\n

If you're looking to find specific search terms to optimize your internal search for, I recommend checking your analytics from last year. By looking at which search terms were searched for in December/January last year, you'll get a good idea for where to start this year.

\n

Share your experiences with us!

\n

Do you check and update your internal search?  We'd love to hear your experiences in the comments below. 

\n

\n \n \n

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nEnterprise Search\n

\n
\n
\n

\n

\nPosted by\nBarbara Hammer-Aebi\n

\n

\n10/24/12 3:42 PM\n

  • \n\nTweet\n

  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Are you planning to launch a mobile version of your website? Here are a few ideas for the design of the search function for the mobile site.

\n

Carefully Selected Content: Website Redesign Tips From a Search Perspective

\n

\nPosted by\nBarbara Hammer-Aebi\n

\n

\n10/3/12 4:05 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

The Siteimprove series on maximizing the potential of a website redesign continues with today's post on the internal search function. We'll take a look at ideas on how your internal search can be used as a helping tool in the general design and testing of your website, as well as guidance on how to best design your search page.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nEnterprise Search\n

\n
\n
\n

Going for gold; developing an elite website

\n

\nPosted by\nBo Vejgaard\n

\n

\n9/26/12 4:08 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Like an athlete at the Olympics, your website should be fit and free from injury. This way you can achieve the best performance and value from your website every day.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nSEO,\nAccessibility,\nEnterprise Search,\nWeb Analytics\n

\n

Create an annual search cycle

\n

\nPosted by\nBarbara Hammer-Aebi\n

\n

\n8/22/12 4:41 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Create an annual search cycle to stay one step ahead of your users

\n
\n

If your website has an internal search bar, it's a good idea to always be working on your internal search statistics. If you want to stay a step ahead of your users, you can create an annual cycle detailing search queries by month.  Then you can track and measure which areas need to be prioritized and given more effort.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nEnterprise Search\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Dive into search statistics

\n

\nPosted by\nBarbara Hammer-Aebi\n

\n

\n6/6/12 10:54 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Search statistics are not only essential for evaluating and maintaining the search function on your website, they are also useful for many other purposes. It is a free opportunity to learn about what your users expect from your website. Do you have the information users need? Is it well organized, and is it easy to click though to the pages that are most sought after?

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nEnterprise Search\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

3 Things you can do to improve your internal search

\n

\nPosted by\nBarbara Hammer-Aebi\n

\n

\n4/11/12 11:34 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

You may think you don’t need to do that? After all, you can find content without doing so. It is essential that you use the internal search regularly. Your search page transforms and looks different depending on which search term you use. Users on your website might view a search result page that you have never seen yourself.

\n
\n

Your search function might be in perfect shape, and not need any adjustments at all. If not, it is time to take control of your internal search function. Since the search function uses the content of the pages on your site the process mostly starts with improving the most important pages.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nEnterprise Search\n

Watch Out, Australia. Here Comes Kelsey.

\n

\nPosted by\nKelsey Johnson\n

\n

\n10/14/14 5:30 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Well, I’m headed down under, to Oz, Aussie, or whatever you prefer to call it – Let me try that again… I’m going to Australia!

\n

Over the past year I’ve had the immense pleasure of working with the Oceania region, and it’s about time that I dropped in for a visit! I’ve been fortunate to build a great network of customers, influencers, and web experts across Australia that I cannot wait to meet with and discuss how Siteimprove can continue to support the needs of web teams around the world, and more specifically, in Australia.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility,\nWeb Governance\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

4 Tips For A Fall Website Cleanup

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n10/7/14 10:02 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Clutter is OK on your desk. Sure, your co-workers will be silently (or not so silently) judging you as stacks of paper, coffee cups, and assorted knick-knacks pile up around your keyboard like garbage in a landfill, but it’s part of your process, right?

\n

Your website, on the other hand, is no place for clutter. Customers expect simple navigation, easy to find information, and useful content. If your website took the summer off to relax, it’s time to put it back to work.

\n

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance,\nContent Governance,\nContent\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

How Web Accessibility Can Boost Your SEO

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n10/6/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

In case having a website that’s accessible to all users wasn’t enough incentive on its own, here’s another reason- it will help boost your SEO rankings. Yeah, true story. On the surface it may not seem like the two are connected, but behind the subtle scenes of your website’s code, proper accessibility practices are providing a major boost to your SEO. What’s that idiom about birds and stones? 

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nSEO,\nAccessibility\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

3 Tips For Creating An Effective Website Content Calendar

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n9/30/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

With the demand for consistent, high-quality web content growing on a daily basis, creating a Content Calendar is the best way to coordinate and organize your content marketing efforts and ensure that your brand remains top of mind with your core audience.

\n

Content Calendars will vary from organization to organization, but by compiling all of your goals, assets, and ideas in a single document, you’ll be able to piece together what can turn into an otherwise unruly and chaotic puzzle.

\n

Ready? Set? Go.

\n

\n
\nRead More\n

Web Accessibility Checklist

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n9/23/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Our reliance on technology in everyday life continues to grow at an alarming rate. I’m willing to wager that the majority of you are reading this on a computer, your smartphone is within arm’s reach, there’s a tablet tucked away in your bag, and you may have even snuck in some TV time today. Some of our closest relationships are the ones we have with our screens and devices, floating in the pixelated waves of the digital sea. Despite how we may feel about being so reliant on our technology, there’s no denying the benefits offered by the latest and greatest gear, gadgets, and gizmos.

\n

\n
\nRead More\n
