Accessible Website Multimedia

\n

\nPosted by\nKevin Rydberg\n

\n

\n9/18/14 12:27 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

According to HubSpot, multimedia content is more engaging and shareable than its text-only counterparts. Making this content more accessible for your users is a simple process, so long as you take web accessibility guidelines into account while adding this kind of content to your website. With improvements in bandwidth, as well as browsers and media players, you have an opportunity to deliver an engaging, rich media experience to your visitors. Unfortunately, if you don’t prepare properly, the experience will be less accessible, and more frustrating to your visitors.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility\n

\n
\n
\n

Website SEO Checklist

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n9/9/14 10:05 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

What Google says, goes. They are the Alpha and Omega when it comes to online search, and their search algorithm is what dictates how your website’s SEO needs to be calibrated. In order to receive the maximum return on your online investment, your website’s SEO needs to cross off a number of key to-do’s before it can reap the rewards from Skynet Google.

\n

If you haven’t been keeping up with Google’s latest algorithm updates, read our blog that discussed the evolving SEO landscape. Go ahead and read it, I’ll wait.

\n
\nRead More\n

Learning From Web Governance Anarchy In The U.K

\n

\nPosted by\nShane Diffily\n

\n

\n9/2/14 9:59 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Have you ever heard the expression "democracy is a precious ambrosia carried around in the rusty bucket of human endeavor"?

\n

Well, rarely has that bucket been more rusty than when applied to governmental web governance.

\n

Experience shows that after lots of initial enthusiasm and conspicuous spending, many official sites quickly go into decline.

\n

The problem is that creating a website is now a box-ticking exercise - characterized by poorly understood goals and inadequate support.

\n

Thankfully, that is starting to change. 

\n

\n
\nRead More\n
\n
\n
\n

Web Accessibility and the Law

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n8/28/14 2:17 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

There is a difference between web accessibility and web usability. For web users with disabilities, the difference often turns their experience with websites into a “yeah, but…” scenario. Yes, the website is technically accessible, but is it usable? Meaning, can the site be navigated in a logical way and can information be accessed with the least amount of obstacles possible? The difference is small on paper, but stark in practice.

\n

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility,\nWeb Governance\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

The Web Governance Food Pyramid

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n8/26/14 10:02 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Don’t worry, I’m not here to tell you that 4 cups of coffee a day and a granola bar for lunch doesn’t constitute proper adult nutrition. In fact, top that off with a pack of Twizzlers® and a Red Bull® and you’ve got yourself the first meal out of the official Corporate America Cookbook (on newsstands never). However, I am going to tell you that your Web Governance Strategy needs to have a solid structure and balanced combination of essential components in order to properly manage and maintain your organization’s online presence.

\n

And what might those components be? I’m glad you asked.

\n

\n
\nRead More\n

Kevin Rydberg

\n
Kevin Rydberg is Siteimprove’s Senior eAccessibility Consultant, in the US office he is responsible for guiding and supporting businesses and organizations on their journeys to create accessible websites. Kevin has spoken across the United States at multiple conferences and events, most recently at the National Council for Marketing and Public Relations National Conference.
\n

Recent Posts

\n
\n
\n

Involving People With Disabilities In Your Web Project

\n

\nPosted by\nKevin Rydberg\n

\n

\n11/4/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Involving people with disabilities on your web projects may seem like an overwhelming task, but if you do, it will be well worth your effort. The benefits will far outweigh the extra work, as you'll be gaining a much deeper understanding of how users with disabilities are motivated, how efficient your site may be, and how effectively all of your users can be while using your site.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility,\nWeb Governance\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Accessible Website Multimedia

\n

\nPosted by\nKevin Rydberg\n

\n

\n9/18/14 12:27 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

According to HubSpot, multimedia content is more engaging and shareable than its text-only counterparts. Making this content more accessible for your users is a simple process, so long as you take web accessibility guidelines into account while adding this kind of content to your website. With improvements in bandwidth, as well as browsers and media players, you have an opportunity to deliver an engaging, rich media experience to your visitors. Unfortunately, if you don’t prepare properly, the experience will be less accessible, and more frustrating to your visitors.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Cognitive Disabilities and Website Accessibility

\n

\nPosted by\nKevin Rydberg\n

\n

\n8/12/14 9:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

While sight and hearing disabilities are the most talked-about when it comes to website accessibility, cognitive disabilities actually represent the largest number of computer users with disabilities according to the National Center on Disability and Access to Education.

\n

So, why aren’t we more aware of cognitive disabilities? Well, because these types of disabilities contain a wide range of nuanced conditions and an even wider range of severity, so it’s difficult to present a comprehensive set of standards to which web developers should comply. 

\n

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Semantic Markup and Web Accessibility

\n

\nPosted by\nKevin Rydberg\n

\n

\n7/17/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Web Content Accessibility Guideline 1.3, “Adaptable” is defined as: Creating content that can be presented in different ways (for example simpler layout) without losing information or structure. 

\n

HTML was originally designed to deliver documents with a structure that represented the importance and order of information. The creators of HTML were actually scientists who wanted a way to share technical documents. They didn’t really care about the visual look of the document as viewed on a screen—it just needed to correctly convey the information.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Website Accessibility and Our Aging Population

\n

\nPosted by\nKevin Rydberg\n

\n

\n6/17/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

How many of you have heard the term “Silver surfer”? A Silver surfer is an individual over the age of 50 who utilizes the Internet on a consistent basis. In this month’s post, we’re going to address the issue of website accessibility and our aging population.

\n

As mentioned in previous posts, approximately 20% of our population is living with some form of disability of varying severity, and thanks to medical and technological advances, that statistic is on the rise due to our aging population.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility,\nWeb Governance\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Global Accessibility Awareness Day: Gain a New Perspective

\n

\nPosted by\nKevin Rydberg\n

\n

\n5/15/14 9:09 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Close your eyes. Now try to read the rest of this paragraph. You didn’t make it very far did you? Imagine how difficult it would be to navigate a website or read a spreadsheet without the aid of assistive technology and website accessibility.

\n

Global Accessibility Awareness Day is aimed at fostering discussions within the design, development, and usability communities as they continue to build, shape, and influence new assistive technologies. The goal is to raise the profile and increase awareness around the topic of digital accessibility, which includes web, mobile, and software experiences. To help spread the word, we're offering our two-part Accessibility Certification Course to everyone for FREE!

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Are You Coding Your Website Data Tables For Accessibility?

\n

\nPosted by\nKevin Rydberg\n

\n

\n5/13/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

We can all agree that using an HTML table for page layout is wrong. For those of you who didn’t know that, thank you for sticking with me into sentence two, I promise this will all make sense if you keep reading. There are many appropriate uses for tables on websites, but the problem lies in understanding the proper way to make those tables accessible for all users. Don’t panic, tables are not to be feared or avoided! With some careful planning and a better understanding of the different table elements and attributes, you too can add usable data tables to your web pages.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

A Look at Assistive Technology

\n

\nPosted by\nKevin Rydberg\n

\n

\n4/15/14 10:37 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Assistive technologies are tools and methods used to make web information available to people with and without disabilities. With the leaps and bounds in technology the last few years, you may not be aware of all of the different kinds of Assistive Technology available.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility,\nAssistive Technologies\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Why Do My Documents Need To Be Accessible?

\n

\nPosted by\nKevin Rydberg\n

\n

\n4/10/14 11:03 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Admit it: “PDFs” aren’t usually the first thing that come to mind when you think about website accessibility. They probably should be. PDFs are nearly ubiquitous as a “final” document type on the web, and hosted PDFs are often the only location certain content is made available – especially for educators, the healthcare industry, and government offices. When they aren’t accessible, that information simply isn’t available to users with disabilities.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Q&A on the Basics of Web Accessibility

\n

\nPosted by\nKevin Rydberg\n

\n

\n2/11/14 9:01 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n

We get a lot of questions on web accessibility here at Siteimprove, and want to take this opportunity to answer as many of them as we can. This may be more of a review for you seasoned accessibility folks, but there’s a growing demand for this introductory information as more web professionals recognize the importance of accessibility. 

\n

\n
\nRead More\n
\n

\n\n\n\n\n\n\n 9792127542:\n\n\n\n\n\nA Web Governance Framework That Works\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n

\n

\nA Web Governance Framework That Works\n

\n

\nPosted by\nJessica O'Sullivan\n

\n

\n10/24/13 4:43 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

The first step in changing Web Governance is often the hardest. There is ample evidence that issues with politics in many organizations have resulted in Governance systems that are extremely resistant to reform. Nevertheless, change must happen eventually. The framework outlined below provides a starting point for this conversation.

\n
\n\n
\n

This article was reprinted with permission from Shane Diffily, Web Governance Consultant and author of The Website Manager's Handbook.

\n

Web Governance (also known as Website Governance) is the discipline that describes how to manage a website in a controlled and orderly way.

\n

Until quite recently few online professionals were much interested in Web Governance. There were too many other problems that needed fixing first, like poor design and content.

\n

But not anymore.

\n

A new generation of executives for whom the web is neither cool nor cryptic are lifting the lid on operations and discovering teams that are badly structured and under-resourced.

\n

To set things right they need a practical framework upon which to build a revised system of Web Governance.

\n

In this article we’ll explore a new model that explains in clear language how Web Governance works and a first step towards changing it for the better.

\n

A new system of Web Governance
At its most basic Web Governance can be defined in terms of just 3 components:

\n

• Governance Activities - These describe everything you must do to manage a website effectively.

\n

• Governance Resources - These describe everything you must have to support the above activities.

\n

• Website Scale - This concept determines how to configure the above Activities & Resources into a workable system of Governance.

\n

Continue Reading…

\n

Shane Diffily, “A Web Governance Framework that works!” Diffily.com, November 2012 http://www.diffily.com/articles/model.htm

\n

\n \n \n

\n\n\n\n\n\n\n 9792151032:\n\n\n\n\n\nWeb Governance Policies and Procedures\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n

\n

\nWeb Governance Policies and Procedures\n

\n

\nPosted by\nBo Vejgaard\n

\n

\n12/5/12 3:05 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Where would an employee go with questions to how a specific task is done on your website?

\n
\n\n
\n

In our previous blog posts about web governance, we give a broad introduction to the topic of web governance as well as a look into coupling web governance with specific topics. In this post I'll talk about web governance policies and procedures.

\n

Why and how

\n

In my blog post about roles and responsibilities in web governance I looked at the Who (roles) and What (responsibilities). Web governance policies answers why you should (and why you shouldn't) do web tasks in a specific way and is comprised of rules that guide the decision making process. Procedures describe how specific web tasks are done, so you can be sure you have a uniform and high quality approach to your website.

\n

Policies and procedures are important because they set the frame for how your web team should work. If an employee has a question to how a task on your website is done, policies and procedure should be the first place to look.

\n

What are policies?

\n

Web governance policies are rules that guide the day-to-day work of your web team and ensure that any laws governing your websites are kept. If there is a reason for doing things in a specific way in relation to your web presence, you should have a policy for it. Policies can cover accessibility compliance, compliance with other rules, laws and standards, social media usage, content review and much more.

\n

Here are a few examples of policies:

\n
    \n
  • When publishing new content to the company website, the content should be reviewed for compliance with the corporate tone-of-voice guidelines.
    • \n
  • All pages on the website must contain a link to our privacy policy.
    • \n
  • When linking to or attaching documents to web pages, these must be uploaded in PDF file format.
    • \n
  • All content on the website should be available in at least English, as this is our corporate language.
    • \n
\n

What are procedures?

\n

Web governance procedures are guidelines that tell you exactly how to do a specific task, to ensure uniformity in the web presence. If you have a web task you want done in the same way, every time it is done, make a procedure for it. Procedures include usage of web analytics, organization of articles, styling and so on.

\n

Here are a few examples of procedures:

\n
    \n
  • Upon uploading a new picture to the media library, you must click on the tab 'crop' and make sure that crops for thumbnails, highlights and sidebars exists.
    • \n
  • When writing a blog post for the corporate blog you must\n
      \n
    • Include all the elements described in the document 'how to write for the company blog.'
      • \n
    • Send the document to the marketing manager for review.
      • \n
    • Send the reviewed document to the UK and DK marketing managers for translation.
      • \n
    • Search statistics must be analyzed on the first Monday of every month in accordance with the document 'Internal search maintenance.'
      • \n
    \n
    • \n
\n

Getting started with policies and procedures

\n

When implementing web governance in your organization it is a great idea to include all members of the web team in the forming of policies and procedures. They probably already follow some unwritten rules of their own, so by starting out with writing these down you'll already have a lot of the work done, while your employees will feel ownership of the policies and procedures.

\n

To make your policies and procedures work, you'll have to make sure they are enforced. A nice way of doing this is to have training sessions where employees get to work with the procedures and can ask questions if needed. A more informal way could be encouraging employees to remind each other of the policies and procedures once in a while.

\n

If you already have implemented a well-functioning web governance with clear roles and responsibilities, and policies and procedures, then I would love to hear from you either in the comments or by email. We would love to hear about you experiences.

\n

\n \n \n

\n
\n
\n

\n

Ahava Leibtag

\n
Ahava is passionate about content and prides herself on tackling the toughest content projects—from healthcare to higher education to hip-hop (seriously). She is the president and owner of Aha Media Group, LLC, a content strategy and content marketing consultancy founded in October 2005. Ahava has more than 15 years of experience in writing, messaging, and marketing, and is a well-recognized content expert. Her first book, The Digital Crown: Winning at Content on the Web was published by Morgan Kaufmann in November 2013
\n
\nFind me on:\n
\n \n
\n
\n
\n

Recent Posts

\n
\n
\n

Why Content Governance Drives Engagement

\n

\nPosted by\nAhava Leibtag\n

\n

\n4/10/14 10:34 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

In honor of President’s Day, my husband and I took our three children to the American Museum of History, a branch of the Smithsonian in Washington, D.C. While we were putting our coats in lockers, I saw something that surprised me:

\n
\n

Does stash seem like a word that is in line with Smithsonian brand? Stash feels a little too irreverent to be a Smithsonian word. Yet, when I saw this sign, it became clear to me:

\n
\nRead More\n

Kevin Rydberg

\n
Kevin Rydberg is Siteimprove’s Senior eAccessibility Consultant, in the US office he is responsible for guiding and supporting businesses and organizations on their journeys to create accessible websites. Kevin has spoken across the United States at multiple conferences and events, most recently at the National Council for Marketing and Public Relations National Conference.
\n
\n

Recent Posts

\n
\n
\n

Putting a Face on Accessibility Part II

\n

\nPosted by\nKevin Rydberg\n

\n

\n7/1/13 10:21 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Professor Chris Olson has had a really busy year. Chris recently bought and moved into a house. Like many home purchases, there was a bit of remodeling that took place before the move to make the space more usable. Chris will be sharing that new home with his fiancé Cindy. Chris and Cindy were engaged on New Year’s Eve. Chris has been teaching graduate and undergraduate level computer and web programming classes for the past seven years. In March 2013, he successfully defended his doctoral dissertation, “Awareness of Accessibility in Computer-based Instructional Materials and Faculty Demographics in South Dakota Public Universities.”

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Kevin’s Top 10 Web Accessibility Tips

\n

\nPosted by\nKevin Rydberg\n

\n

\n5/28/13 3:24 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Web accessibility is a complex issue, and there are many rules and guidelines that you need to be aware of as you work towards providing an accessible solution for your users. One of the most frequent questions we hear is, “where do I start?” Here are 10 items to consider when building accessible websites. Whether you are contributing content to a blog, or managing thousands of pages, these tips should put you on the right path.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Putting a Face on Accessibility

\n

\nPosted by\nKevin Rydberg\n

\n

\n4/29/13 10:25 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

All too often we forget to put a face on people with disabilities, instead we lump them into categories.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

\n\n\n\n\n\n\n \n
\n\n\n\n\n\n\n 9792139582:\n\n\n\n\n\nHow to Win Friends and Influence Your Web Team\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
    \n

    • \n

    • \n

\n
\n
\n
\n

\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n

Siteimprove Web Governance Blog

\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n

\nHow to Win Friends and Influence Your Web Team\n

\n

\nPosted by\nDave Schneider\n

\n

\n2/5/14 8:52 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n

Stop me if you’ve heard this one: You’re the website manager, and you’re held responsible for the quality of your web content - but you have content contributors from other departments over whom you hold no real power. That means you’re held accountable for the quality of their work, but have no way to make them actually do it. If they decide not to fix issues that come up, it reflects poorly on you. Fortunately, there are ways to manage this situation! Since you don’t have administrative influence over these team members, you’ll have to rely on relational influence – which is better anyway.

\n
\n
\n

Here are five ways to win friends and win over the most obstinate of your web editors when you don’t have the power to force them do their work:

\n

1. Don’t criticize them

\n

Criticism won’t motivate them to perform better; it will only make them dislike you. Yes, even if you’re right. Avoid the temptation to “vent” to a coworker. Although you may be expressing honest frustration with a colleague you trust, those conversations tend to find their way around the office. Momentarily feeling a release of frustration isn’t worth the risk of making a lifelong political enemy.

\n

Instead of criticizing them, take a look at your monitoring and analytics tools to determine the areas of weakness empirically, and then work to understand how your discoveries affect them in their role. Using these tools allows you to approach them with a “new discovery” based on facts, rather than a negative personal opinion of their work. Always approach them as a colleague working to help them solve their problems, instead of a Philistine taking potshots from another department.

\n

2. Don’t argue with them

\n

Never approach them with the intention of forcing them to admit the error of their ways, because it simply never works. They’ll instantly go into defense mode, and fight you on everything. Swallow your need “to be heard” (AKA pride), and verbally acknowledge their objections as legitimate concerns deserving of carefully thought out answers. You never know when you might have overlooked something.

\n

Instead of arguing, use project management tools to clearly define issues and responsibility for everyone involved with your website, not just your offending party. As the proverb goes, “it takes a village.” Be careful not to single them out, and let the numbers speak for themselves. Chances are they’re smart enough to put two and two together on their own, even if they never let it show on the outside.

\n

3. Help them save face

\n

Now that you’ve discovered the issues empirically and clearly defined responsibility, downplay the fault and make it seem easily correctable. Be careful to only talk about the issues as privately as possible, and focus on the positives.  If other contributor jurisdictions have only a few errors, and theirs has dozens, present it as the area with the “most potential for improvement,” rather than the “worst section of the website.”

\n

Take great care to be tactful, because you can either win or get them to admit they’re wrong - not both.

\n

4. Speak their language

\n

Everyone is tuned into the same radio station: WIIFM (What’s In It For Me?). Step into their shoes and look at the situation from their perspective.  How does their participation in managing the website help them personally? Why should they want to help you?  Help them see how this isn’t just another menial task being dumped on them by someone who isn’t their boss.

\n

The best way to do this is to show how the issues may be affecting conversions in their area of the website, which may not always be a black and white metric. It’s easy if there are demo signup forms or something is for sale on the website, but what if you’re more informational, like a city government site? Departments may not feel like they have any “news” to share, and allow their content to become stale. What if your conversions happen offline, like when students visit a university website before sending an application in the mail?  In cases like these, you’ll have to spend a little more time thinking what the basic offerings of those pages are, and how they’re measured.  Are people downloading city maps, signing up for a newsletter, etc.? Are applicants downloading the application form from the website? What are the goals of that section of the website, and how do issues impede them?

\n

5. Lavish them with sincere praise for small successes

\n

Finally, positive reinforcement works wonders.  No matter how poorly you feel they’re doing, there’s always SOMETHING you can praise them for and mean it. Make sure you never give insincere praise, because it makes you look phony and manipulative. Find the positives and praise them as publicly and specifically as you can as often as possible.

\n

If everyone else fixes their small handful of issues immediately, and they fix a dozen of their hundred issues in a week or two, promote them as the person who made the largest headway.

\n

Ready to try your hand at motivating your team members? Remember these five tips, and let us know how it goes! Also, if you haven’t read Dale Carnegie’s How to Win Friends and Influence People, I can’t recommend it highly enough.

\n
\n
\n \n \n
\n
\n

\n

\nWhat is Web Accessibility?\n

\n

\nPosted by\nHelene Nørgaard Bech\n

\n

\n3/21/12 11:48 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n

The term “Accessibility” is often used broadly, but there is a clear definition of what we mean: ensuring that as many users as possible can navigate and comprehend a website.

\n
\n

Being in the accessibility industry, I meet many web professionals with differing thoughts on what web accessibility is. Some think that it's all about uptime and response time (Availability), others say usability, and some say search engine optimization (SEO) or "find-ability." Some believe that accessibility means that everything on your website can be read aloud in an automated way. I think you get the idea.

\n\n

The truth is that web accessibility is made up of many things. And yes, uptime on a website fundamentally relates to whether your website is accessible for the users or not. There are also many parallels between optimizing your website for accessibility and SEO - because a search engine is also a type of user. Having the option of having things read aloud on the website is also a part of accessibility, but just a small part of the overall picture.

\n

So who defines what web accessibility is and where can this definition be found?

\n

The organization responsible for standardizing the internet is called the "W3C" (World Wide Web Consortium).  The W3C is a non-profit organization founded and headed by Tim Berners Lee, and they have a working group called WAI (Web Accessibility Initiative). WAI defines web accessibility and they compose guidelines on how to ensure good web accessibility.

\n

The standards set by W3C are globally recognized, so you can safely use these guidelines as a definition of the area. The set of guidelines that cover websites are called Web Content Accessibility Guidelines (WCAG) and helps to ensure that as many web users as possible can use a website. The guidelines are formulated in such a way that by designing your website to comply, you also ensure a robustness that allows "user agents" (a fancy name for things like browsers and screen readers) to show and interpret your web pages.

\n

The WAI make a point of listening to comments and suggestions, taking them very seriously.

\n

As with most technical guideline documents, the structure and communication of the WCAG documents is unfortunately fairly complex.  It can take a lot of work to understand and interpret the meaning of the different criteria.

\n

To add to the complexity, in most web projects you will not be responsible for implementing all of the criteria. Usually, you'll need to pick out the areas that are relevant to your specific role.

\n

For developers, one set of criteria may be relevant to you, while a different set of criteria would be relevant to a CMS provider, or a web content editor, etc.

\n

In a series of future blog posts we will discuss these different sets of criteria.

\n

You can also look forward to a whitepaper on web accessibility which will be published on this website.

\n

\n \n \n

\n
\n

Topics:\nAccessibility\n

\n\n\n\n\n\n\n 9792150202:\n\n\n\n\n\nThe three components of Content Strategy success\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n

Siteimprove Web Governance Blog

\n

\n
\n

\nThe three components of Content Strategy success\n

\n

\nPosted by\nJack Oldham\n

\n

\n4/8/13 2:48 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Creating effective website content can be an arduous task, especially when so many factors must be considered: varying role capacities, internal politics, customer expectations etc. However, following a structured strategy can make creating focused content a piece of cake!

\n
\n\n
\n

In recent years, as the term ‘content strategy’ has gained momentum, the working definition has shifted and shaped a little, with many industry experts now accepting it as the plans for the creation, publication, and governance of useful, usable content. What exactly does this all mean though and what impact does content strategy have on your organization?

\n

According to Kristina Halvorson, recognized as one of the industry’s leading advocates for content strategy, the benefits of having a strong content strategy are abundant. Halvorson argues that “High-quality web content that's useful, usable, and enjoyable is one of the greatest competitive advantages you can create for yourself online.”  

\n

Yet understanding the term ‘content strategy’ and actually applying it in real life are two different things, which is why we’re going to dissect these three main components to success:

\n
    \n
  1. \n

    Creation

    \n
    2. \n
  2. \n

    Publication

    \n
    3. \n
  3. \n

    Governance

    \n
    4. \n
\n

1. Creation

\n

One common content strategy mistake is to undervalue the creation process. When planning a new website, many organizations will focus too much on the graphical specifications, instead of curating useful and usable content.

\n

Therefore, beginning the creation phase, especially the re-creation phase for an existing website, can be challenging but there are plenty of solutions available to you. Firstly, consider what data you may need to help you in formulating content. A good analytics tool should be able to give you an in-depth insight into how your developing site or existing sites content is meeting and engaging people’s expectations and needs. From mapping user journeys, to understanding where users come from, it all helps in deciding on what content to create or use.

For more information about how analytics can assist in the content creation phase check out Web Analytics expert, Bo Vejgaard’s blog ‘Get inspiration from your analytics data when planning a new website.’ Another useful device to consider using during this stage is a tool such as Siteimprove SEO, which is ideal for figuring out whether content is optimized for keywords and search engines.        

\n

2. Publication

\n

The publication stage in which content finally goes live is both exciting and daunting. During this time it’s important not to become complacent, as an excellent content strategy is one that is ongoing. Due diligence during this stage is just as essential as it was during creation. Part of this diligence means ensuring that all published content is thoroughly reviewed and checked. Now while this may seem like a bigger task than creating content in the first place, there are resources that can help you.

\n

One solution is to consider investing in a quality assurance tool. A good QA tool should be able to identify spelling mistakes, internal and external broken links, as well as provide a complete overview of all media files that are currently published on your website. All this helps ensure your website’s content credibility remains protected. Additionally it should also be able to assign responsibilities so that everyone’s publications roles are clearly defined, which sets a high ongoing publication standard.

\n

Those interested in making their content inclusive should also consider the role accessibility plays in content publishing. Although it can be very technical based, adhering to international guidelines for web accessibility ensures that as many users as possible can navigate and comprehend your site. Take a look at some of our previous blogs to learn more, such as what exactly web accessibility is.    

\n

3. Governance

\n

Once created and published many organizations tend to adopt a ‘done and dusted’ policy, rather than enforcing a proactive content governance model. Without such a model organizations are unable to ensure contents consistency - which is a waste of time and money. To implement a web governance model there are four key aspects to consider:

\n
    \n
  1. \n

    Tools

    \n
    2. \n
  2. \n

    Authority

    \n
    3. \n
  3. \n

    Maintenance

    \n
    4. \n
  4. \n

    Measurement

    \n
    5. \n
\n

Tools such as a web governance suite are great for ensuring the other aspects are in order. Different tools within the suite, such as a quality assurance tool, make it is easy to assign authority and responsibility, while a monitoring tool will greatly assist in ensuring a website’s maintenance, and analytics and SEO take the guesswork out of measurement.          

\n

Stay tuned for our next installments

\n

Throughout the upcoming series we will be delving deeper into the three necessary components for content strategy success, their common issues, as well as offering you specific solutions to these problems.

\n
\n
\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance\n

\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n

\n\n\n\n\n\n\n 9792150332:\n\n\n\n\n\nSanta Isn't Real: 4 Common Website Redesign Myths\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
    \n

    • \n
  • Industries
    • \n

    • \n
  • About
    • \n

\n

\nSanta Isn't Real: 4 Common Website Redesign Myths\n

\n

\nPosted by\nDave Schneider\n

\n

\n12/12/13 9:38 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Website redesigns tend to be treated as a magic cure for a poor web presence by many digital marketers today. Unfortunately for them, separating fact from fiction can be a sobering wake up call. Here are the top 4 myths surrounding website redesign projects today:

\n
\n\n
\n

1. "My new website will be in perfect condition when it launches"

\n

Unfortunately, buying a new website isn’t like buying a new car.

\n

While buying cars and websites both require lots of planning and research to find the right one, new cars typically don’t have serious mechanical issues when they roll out the factory door. Websites do.  Ask any veteran web developer if they plan to flip the “on switch” for a new website right before the whole team goes home for the weekend, and they’ll either burst into laughter or tears.

\n

A better analogy would be a heart transplant.

\n

You spend countless hours transferring things over from the old site, redirecting links, double and triple checking your work before sewing it up and saying a prayer. Then you spend the next month in observation keeping a close watch on the vitals hoping to catch all the complications and prevent a catastrophe.

\n

Common side effects include:

\n
    \n
  • Images and pages linked to the old site instead of being re-uploaded
    • \n
  • Large images resized in the browser
    • \n
  • Content copied from the old website carrying over mistakes
    • \n
  • New content inevitably creating new misspellings and broken links 
    • \n
\n

Yes, even if you hired an agency

\n

Mistakes are inevitable, even for the most elite professionals. When you’re dealing with the heart of your online presence you can’t afford to let it skip a single beat.  The customer getting 404’d by your ‘Contact Support’ page doesn’t care whether your web design agency promised a flawless website or Fabio riding a unicorn. You don't have either and they’re frantic.

\n

2. "The redesign will fix all my current problems"

\n

Many problems simply can’t be fixed by website redesigns. A decentralized web team lacking clear roles means anyone can create and remove pages as they see fit, so starting over from scratch is only placing a fresh bandage on a gunshot wound. You’ll be back to the Wild West in no time.

\n

Other problems can be fixed, but bring new issues with them:
Getting rid of outdated web content, inefficient menu structures, etc. can have a catastrophic effect on your search engine rankings. When you remove web pages or change the URLs, you lose all the inbound links you’ve built up over the years - unless you set up a 301 redirect for each one. It's a pain if you only have 40 pages, (spoiler: you have a lot more than 40 pages) but it's an impossible goal if you have 2,000 pages. Since you’re restructuring your website, a lot of those pages probably won’t exist on the new site to be redirected to anyway.

\n

If you keep any of your old web content, there’s almost a guarantee you’ll keep some of your old errors. If the most skilled web agencies in the world still make mistakes, you can bet your content contributors are human too.

\n

3. "My web agency will make the website accessible to disabled users"

\n

No. They won’t.

\n

…Okay, maybe I should explain a little:

\n

Website accessibility is a complex, ongoing practice. It‘s impossible for any web agency to guarantee a fully accessible website because accessibility has to be continuously maintained by your web team. Your heart surgeon can’t promise a life free of heart problems just like your agency can’t promise you a fully accessible website.

\n

A few common post-op issues that can’t be prevented by an agency:

\n
    \n
  • Using directional cues for instructions (“click the button to the right” – if a visitor is vision impaired, they may use a program that reads the website to them directly from the HTML. There is no “right” or “left”)
    • \n
  • Not using descriptive ALT text for images (reader programs and search engines can’t decipher what your JPEG is a picture of. This is especially a problem if you've put a graph inside a picture)
    • \n
  • Having all your hyperlink text be “Click Here!” (mobile users, vision impaired, and just about everyone else won’t have a clue where you’re linking)
    • \n
\n

Also, if you don’t test your web accessibility independently, how will you know whether your web agency is delivering on their promises?

\n

Shameless plug: Siteimprove offers free online web accessibility certification courses to our customers, and you can enroll in the courses by emailing our certification team. If you're not a customer, there's no time like right now to make a hasty impulse purchase!

\n

4. "We’re starting the redesign next month, so fixing our current site is pointless"

\n

A well planned website redesign project can easily take 6 months to complete when properly managed. But website redesigns are infamous for delays and scope creep for good reason: just about everyone in your company has an opinion on the website, and they’ll come out of the woodwork to voice it.

\n

Even the simplest decisions commonly meet death by committee. It’s not unusual for us here at Siteimprove to talk to teams who are months into a redesign and have almost agreed to a top level navigation structure.

\n

In the meantime your current website is visited all day, every day by people who need it to work right now. Maintaining top-notch quality hasn’t lost any importance to them, and it shouldn’t for you either.

\n

Siteimprove can help

\n

Check out our free ebook on How to Prepare for a Website Redesign.

\n

\n \n \n

\n

Have any redesign myths to add? Let us know in the comments section below.

\n
\n
\n

\n\n\n\n\n\n\n 9792153932:\n\n\n\n\n\nHigher Education & The Web: Reaching Your Audience\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n\n

\n

\n
\n
\n

\nHigher Education & The Web: Reaching Your Audience\n

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n8/7/14 10:30 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n

Finding the right medium for communicating with the most tech-savvy generations can be difficult. With the abundance of devices, platforms, and channels available to students these days, universities and colleges are forced to make difficult choices. Do they focus their attention on a select number of channels, or do they try to spread their efforts across as many as possible in the hopes of reaching the largest audience possible? There may not be a single right answer for every institution, but recent trends should help make finding those answers easier.

\n

The recently published 2014 E-Expectations Report from Noel-Levitz, OmniUpdate, CollegeWeekLive, and NRCCUA sheds some light on how students and their parents prefer to interact with the universities on their wish list. You can get the E-Expectation Report here.

\n

The report provides some interesting findings regarding how students and parents prefer to communicate with universities over a wide range of channels and mediums. Some stats that caught our eye are:

\n
    \n
  • Parents and students both rated college websites as the most influential and reliable recruitment resource by a significant margin.
    • \n
  • 62% of students and 51% of parents prefer web-based resources for learning about prospective universities.
    • \n
  • 67% of students and 59% of parents indicated that a university’s website experience affects their perception of the institution.
    • \n
  • 96% of students and 85% of parents will open an email from a university they are considering.
    • \n
  • 71% of students are viewing university websites on their mobile devices, yet only 41% of them have completed an action, such as requesting information or applying for enrollment.
    • \n
  • Only 51% of students have “liked” a university’s Facebook page, and only 37% have followed them on Twitter.
    • \n
  • Only 38% of students and 50% of parents prefer phone calls and printed materials.
    • \n
\n

 

\n

“Overwhelmingly, students and parents expressed a preference for good website experiences” – 2014 E-Expectation Report

\n
\n
\n

 

\n

While the preference for communication via digital channels doesn’t come as a surprise, the high marks for mobile use, and equally low marks for social media do peak our interest.

\n

Web experiences on mobile devices continue to grow exponentially with each school year. However, many websites (not just university sites) are not able to provide the same experience on a mobile device that they are able to provide with their traditional website. Interacting with forms, downloading information, and viewing videos are often difficult if they have not been properly optimized for mobile platforms. This is evidenced by the fact that of the 71% of students who viewed a site on their mobile device, no more than 41% completed a measurable action.

\n

\n

The lack of interaction between students and universities across social media (shown in the graph below) is a bit surprising, as social platforms should offer a unique opportunity for students to interact in real-time with the university, and for universities to show their unique value proposition. 

\n

\n

The take away here might be to reconsider the content you’re posting to your social feeds. If students and parents are looking to your website for reliable information about enrollment and academic programs, you can help them find it faster by posting it directly to your social feed. By focusing on the most important questions, like degree tracts, faculty or university awards and recognition, or financial aid opportunities, you'll make it easier for your audience to find the information they seek, and develop a stronger connection with your university.

\n

With such a high number of prospective students relying on web interactions before choosing the institution that they will call home for the next 4 years, the statistics presented in the Noel-Levitz report reinforce the importance of having a consistent and high-quality website experience.

\n

Make sure your website is setup to provide the best possible user experience for excited students and discerning parents.

\n

\n \n \n

\n

Top image courtesy of franky242 at FreeDigitalPhotos.net

\n

All data/graph images courtesy of Noel-Levitz 2014 E-Expectations Report at NoelLevitz.com

\n
\n

\n

\n3 Tips for Preparing for a Website Redesign\n

\n

\nPosted by\nStar Bazella\n

\n

\n4/10/14 10:16 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n

Website redesign projects are all the rage in marketing today. According to recent studies, the vast majority of marketing departments have either just undergone a website redesign, or are just about to. However, many marketers can’t give an empirical reason for their redesign. They know their current website is “underperforming,” and that’s about it. Without clearly and empirically determining how and why your website is underperforming, a redesign is little more than a really expensive and stressful shot in the dark.

\n
\n

1. Define the purpose of your redesign

\n

The first step to a successful website redesign is to ask the question “Why are we doing a redesign?” That might sound obvious, but you’d be surprised how many websites get redesigned without anyone creating a solid answer to that question. Your gut instinct that the website is ugly, or the user experience is underperforming may be accurate, but without further exploration your next redesign will likely be no better. Use data, not your gut, to add definition to the question “why.”

\n

You should structure each redesign goal in three layers:

\n
    \n
  1. What part of the website specifically is underperforming, and how does it tie into the goal of your website?
    2. \n
  2. Redefine the goal based on the data you’ve collected
    3. \n
  3. Determine why this goal is important to your organization
    4. \n
\n

2. Use data for decision making and planning

\n

Data is extremely useful for helping us to ask the right questions – it doesn’t provide the answers! You need to create experiments to test theories on why the data shows what it does.

\n

Use the data to:

\n
    \n
  • Identify the problems
    • \n
  • Refine your understanding of those problems
    • \n
  • Define questions that will lead to solutions to the problems
    • \n
\n

Now that you’ve formulated questions based on hard data, use your intuition to make educated guesses as to the answers to the questions provided by your data, and then test your hypothesis with experiments.

\n

3. Web accessibility matters

\n

Web accessibility is the inclusive practice of making websites usable by people of all abilities and disabilities. Without intentional effort, you may exclude some users from being able to properly use the new website you’ve spent so much energy creating.

\n

Making your website accessible has its benefits:

\n
    \n
  • Social responsibility (it’s the right thing to do)
    • \n
  • Larger customer base (studies show that 20% of the US population claims a disability)
    • \n
  • Efficient Code (search engines and users with disabilities have many characteristics in common)
    • \n
\n

Want to learn more about preparing for a website redesign? Check out our on-demand webinar, “How to Prepare for a Website Redesign.”

\n

\n \n \n

\n
\n
\n

Topics:\nWebsite Redesign\n

3 Tips For Creating An Effective Website Content Calendar

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n9/30/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

With the demand for consistent, high-quality web content growing on a daily basis, creating a Content Calendar is the best way to coordinate and organize your content marketing efforts and ensure that your brand remains top of mind with your core audience.

\n

Content Calendars will vary from organization to organization, but by compiling all of your goals, assets, and ideas in a single document, you’ll be able to piece together what can turn into an otherwise unruly and chaotic puzzle.

\n

Ready? Set? Go.

\n

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance,\nContent Governance,\nContent,\nWebsite Redesign\n

\n
\n

Web Accessibility Checklist

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n9/23/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Our reliance on technology in everyday life continues to grow at an alarming rate. I’m willing to wager that the majority of you are reading this on a computer, your smartphone is within arm’s reach, there’s a tablet tucked away in your bag, and you may have even snuck in some TV time today. Some of our closest relationships are the ones we have with our screens and devices, floating in the pixelated waves of the digital sea. Despite how we may feel about being so reliant on our technology, there’s no denying the benefits offered by the latest and greatest gear, gadgets, and gizmos.

\n

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility,\nWeb Governance\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Website SEO Checklist

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n9/9/14 10:05 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

What Google says, goes. They are the Alpha and Omega when it comes to online search, and their search algorithm is what dictates how your website’s SEO needs to be calibrated. In order to receive the maximum return on your online investment, your website’s SEO needs to cross off a number of key to-do’s before it can reap the rewards from Skynet Google.

\n

If you haven’t been keeping up with Google’s latest algorithm updates, read our blog that discussed the evolving SEO landscape. Go ahead and read it, I’ll wait.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nSEO,\nWeb Governance,\nContent Governance\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Web Accessibility and the Law

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n8/28/14 2:17 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

There is a difference between web accessibility and web usability. For web users with disabilities, the difference often turns their experience with websites into a “yeah, but…” scenario. Yes, the website is technically accessible, but is it usable? Meaning, can the site be navigated in a logical way and can information be accessed with the least amount of obstacles possible? The difference is small on paper, but stark in practice.

\n

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility,\nWeb Governance\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

The Web Governance Food Pyramid

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n8/26/14 10:02 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Don’t worry, I’m not here to tell you that 4 cups of coffee a day and a granola bar for lunch doesn’t constitute proper adult nutrition. In fact, top that off with a pack of Twizzlers® and a Red Bull® and you’ve got yourself the first meal out of the official Corporate America Cookbook (on newsstands never). However, I am going to tell you that your Web Governance Strategy needs to have a solid structure and balanced combination of essential components in order to properly manage and maintain your organization’s online presence.

\n

And what might those components be? I’m glad you asked.

\n

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Higher Education & The Web: Reaching Your Audience

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n8/7/14 10:30 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Finding the right medium for communicating with the most tech-savvy generations can be difficult. With the abundance of devices, platforms, and channels available to students these days, universities and colleges are forced to make difficult choices. Do they focus their attention on a select number of channels, or do they try to spread their efforts across as many as possible in the hopes of reaching the largest audience possible? There may not be a single right answer for every institution, but recent trends should help make finding those answers easier.

\n

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Using Web Analytics To Improve Your Content

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n8/5/14 11:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

So. You’ve got a website and it’s super swanky, what with all the bright colors, pretty designs, and such. It’s also probably filled with content that you’ve spent hours creating, cultivating, and curating. But is that content any good? I mean really, how do you know? Of course YOU think it’s good, you wrote it. No offense, but you don’t matter. If your audience doesn’t think your content is relevant or helpful, then you’re just wasting words. But people don’t always say what they mean or mean what they say, so how can you truly tell if your content is resonating with your audience? Analytics.

\n

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Analytics,\nContent\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Web Governance Ask Us Anything Preview #2

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n7/29/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n

As our panel of experts are busy answering the brain-busting questions submitted for our Ask Us Anything, we thought we'd share a sneak peek at the wisdom of our friend and Web Governance expert, Shane Diffily.

\n

You can download the full Ask Us Anything recording here.

\n

OK, I know. "Stop talking and give us the goods." 

\n

\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

The Web Governance Checklist

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n7/22/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Every organization has different goals for their online presence, a unique team managing that presence, and a distinct process for achieving their goals. What I’m trying to say, is that there’s no golden ticket, silver bullet, or metaphor in the world that will solve every organization’s web governance needs. However, there are plenty of ways to get your web governance endeavors started off on the right (or left) foot.

\n

Whether you’re just getting your organization’s web governance strategy in place, or need to get yours back to basics, here are a few areas to focus on.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Ask Us Anything Preview

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n7/15/14 12:48 PM\n

We're in a giving mood today, so we thought we'd share a quick preview of what you can expect to learn from our upcoming Ask Us Anything session.

Siteimprove Web Governance Suite: The only web governance software that helps you better manage and maintain your website through quality assurance, accessibility, web analytics, SEO, and response – all in one tool.
